The iPad's external buttons are well placed and feel nice to operate. The Kindle's are adequate and do the job as designed but are nothing special.PerformanceHere's where things get interesting. This Camry of tablets has an ace up it's sleeve, almost as if some insane person at TRD (Toyota Racing Division) got hold of it and bolted on a supercharger while also fitting it with nitrous. When it comes to watching video, listening to music, reading books, using apps and web browsing the Kindle is on par and in some cases better performing than the iPad.Web browsingiPad is better and smoother to react to user input via the touch screen but the Kindle is almost as good and very much improved over the original 7" Kindle Fire.AppsNo doubt about it, the Camry is a much cheaper to run compared to the Aston. One of the big advantages over Apple as it comes to apps, Amazon gives one away for free in it's App Store everyday and on some apps lets you try them for a period of time under the aptly named "Test Drive". They aren't just cheap apps no one wants or "scam apps" that give you little content and expect you to spend extra $ on "in app" purchases. This is great if you have kids or like to play games on your tablet as many of the free apps are games and they are usually quite entertaining.Video/ScreenMuch like the Camry might have a better nav system than the Aston, the Kindle is an awesome device for streaming video, especially through Amazon Video on Demand. A big bonus is that if you're a "Prime" member there's a decent amount of TV shows and movies that you can stream for free. I was one of the early Prime members who loved it just for the free two-day shipping, so the streaming video was like icing on the cake. Netflix is here as well and is great. I see apps for Hulu and some others but haven't tried them. Between Netflix and Amazon VOD your video needs will be well covered IMO. The screen is sharp, bright and the interface is quite engaging and attractive to look at.Music/SoundThis Camry has had some serious upgrades at the local car audio store. The sound is spectacular, rich and loud. Flat out blows away the iPad and any other portable device I have ever used. I now officially favor Amazon's MP3 store over iTunes and buy all my music from it. The songs are stored free on the cloud and easily import into iTunes as an MP3 file so I can add them to my iPod and iPhone as needed.Magazines/NewsstandOn par with the iPad and a thousand times better than the old 7" Kindle (which was horrible for magazines due to its screen size). I find the Amazon magazine store much easier to use than Apple's.BooksAmazon's the king here, both in shopping for books and in reading them on the device.4G and Skype/Video Chat - Haven't tried these options yet.If the difference of a few hundred dollars isn't important and the need to have a sexy looking tablet is then check out the iPad. As I can imagine if you owned an Aston for some time but could no longer afford it, it would likely dampen and otherwise dull your driving experience in a Camry. In that respect in some ways I wish I could go back in time and never even have purchased the iPad. If I could and the Kindle was the only tablet I had ever used I would think it the most brilliant device ever invented. But personally I am a sucker for a stunning exterior design and "teutonic-like" build quality and in many respects have to give the iPad the advantage over the Kindle.However a good lot of us can't afford the iPad or simply don't want to spend the extra $ and for those folks the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" is a brilliant companion packed with value. This holds true both in terms of the purchase price of the device and the "extras" Amazon gives you in terms of free apps and video streaming (if you're a Prime member). Oh, and don't let the "special offers" version of the tablet scare you off. I have no idea why this bothers people, all it involves is when you put the Kindle in "sleep" mode an ad appears on the screen. There's no annoying pop-ups or anything like what you would experience browsing the web on a computer, it's simply an ad that appears when the device is locked or woken-up. In fact it's just like driving by a billboard in your Camry, sometimes it might catch your eye and you'll take notice but in most instances you'll just look away and keep driving. :)
Reviews.Title: The 2013 Toyota Camry of Tablets

Reviews.Author: Jraptor
Reviews.Content: This is my last edit of this review. I put the current event at the top of this review, Jan 20th, 2013. Read the entries below the first one, if you wish, for more information.I am returning my Kindle 8.9 Fire. I do not really want to, because I wanted this device to work, but it is just too terribly flawed not to return. My first 8.9 had broken speakers. Amazon kindly replaced it, but the replacement was even worse. If you use the browser and try to access more than 3 sites in a row, it hard crashes and restarts. It is extremely slow..the videos tear and stutter (not just internet activities, it does it on the fully downloaded movies and books too). It randomly shuts off and restarts itself. Maybe it is because I bought the expensive one and it exceeds the $299 design, but I have lost my faith in the device. I have used it for about 2 weeks, trying to make it work, and it finally became so frustrating that I asked for a refund. I am very sad about this. I have 3 other kindles including two of the first gen Fires and I loved them. Something has changed in Amazons business strategy or another factor, I think, with this device. It simply does not measure up to the previous versions of the Kindles.++ The 8.9 has some small annoyances, such as no on/charger light, hard to find recessed buttons, and the charger input being on the longer side of the display, so plugging it in and watching a movie is impossible. One week into ownership, the speakers on one side of my kindle stopped working. I tried a factory reset, and tested different media, all to no effect. I was going to ask for a refund, but the Amazon people were so nice to me I decided to get a replacement instead. They are getting it to me quickly and at no extra charge. I will continue to document on this device and let you know the results. I have gotten such excellent service and my other Kindles are great and I am still satisfied if the replacement takes care of the problem. I am sure out of the thousands of reviews, this will be the important one! :)  (JK)+++The new device is working well. I bought the expensive one, with 64mb storage and WiFi. I think it may have been a mistake. Apple designs their pad to be a expensive device. Kindle is designed to be a cheap device. When you add allot of things into something designed to be the low end, it increases the likely hood something will go wrong.++++The 4G provider, AT&T;, is the anti-christ of companies. I really hate that amazon has a business deal with them, and that their demonic logo appears on the kindle. If you aren't familiar with AT&T;, check out their history. It is one of the most customer hostile, money grubbing, POS companies in the world. The government has split them up, but they just reform in a few years.
Reviews.Title: Two returns of a faulty product. Refund issued. Sorry Kindle :(

Reviews.Author: CVA "Craig"
Reviews.Content: WARNING:  Multiple issues exist versus prior Kindle models, including how 4G use is configured.  My older Kindle DX has 3G service, and had NO Wi-Fi capability.  The new Kindle Fire HD depends on and requires Wi-Fi usage alongside 4G.  So if your Wi-Fi is poor, like mine, you are SOL even with 4G.  WARNING:  The TTS function now works only with books.  Not newspapers or blogs!And the $49 offer for AT&T; 4G service advertised, depends upon which of the two billing arrangements you make on Kindle setup.  AT&T; is going to bill me $216/year instead, and it is NOT clearly indicated before you make the choice.Even worse, the AT&T; 4G service is of limited function. !!!  This afternoon I found out that in order to watch a movie, or even download a magazine,  I had to reconnect my "Wi Fi" connection, and use that instead of the AT&T; 4G.  So I do not understand what the premium of the 4G service is good for.After reconnecting the Wi Fi, the one movie I tried to watch kept stopping. Why? Because my Wi Fi connection is not strong, and the Kindle was "hunting for Wi-Fi signal" which was the purpose I intended in paying more for the 4G service!.Speaking of blogs . . .THERE ARE NO BLOGS!  I subscribe to The Huffington Post and New York Times Latest News "blogs",  which provide updates throughout the day.  The Kindle Fire HD does not support these.The other major complaint I have is about the TTS "Text to Speech" feature.  Amazon and other forum reps represented that the TTS feature would be installed on the Fire HD models, subject to publisher support, but that is NOT completely true.  The TTS feature was an important function to me, as I have used my older Kindle DX model. On the Kindle DX, the TTS works with most books, AND with newspaper/blog downloads as well.  I have discovered that with the Fire HD TTS does NOT work with any newspaper/blogs --- only with books.  So not a publisher decision.  A design difference.Why was that important to me as a loyal Kindle customer??  Because like many,  I have a long commute,  and I was using the Kindle DX with TTS to read me the headlines and in depth stories from the New York Times, or Washington Post,  or other periodicals,  during my commute.  Along with the books.  The loss of the TTS feature on periodicals was NOT disclosed in the advertising on the Kindle Fire.  For those of us that used TTS on prior models,  reading that the new model supported TTS as well,  it certainly implied that the feature was not being diminished ---- ie by the loss of all newspaper and blog support.  Indeed,  that is why I bought the 4G version,  because that was a great feature of my 3G equipped Kindle DX.Back to my Kindle DX.  Who needs to see fancy book covers in color instead?  They have the right to change features.  But the loss of functionality is a big step back and NOT YET PROPERLY DISCLOSED.
Reviews.Title: The 4G model depends on Wi-Fi to stream movies!  The TTS text-to-speech feature no longer supports newspapers/ blogs!

Reviews.Author: frustrsted
Reviews.Content: ordered and paid for a new kindle fire HD 8.9 on 12/10/2012, received it on 12/18/2012; excited at beginning, but disappointed after seeing a previous owner's ID after powering it up. doubt about the reason why it's being returned....Well, if it works...but instead,this piece of junk reboot itself many times when I am on internet. it disrupting....It does this every day till it frozen and quit today whit power on. I am putting my figure on power switch for long time, it has no response whatsoever....same frozen page and I can do nothing. Called Amazon, went through 3 representative and 30 minutes on the phone, why....Be very careful, amazon can sell an used product but charge consumer a brand new price without disclosure.
Reviews.Title: pay for a new,but got a used one, not working most time, die today

Reviews.Author: bookmagic
Reviews.Content: Updated-11/28/12 I thought charging problems were related to problems with my Kindle e-reader charger. I purchased the power charger and things seem to be better. However, when I plug it in to charge, it does not always start charging and I have to unplug it, wait, etc. And now I noticed that it isn't holding the charge very well. I called Amazon and they are sending me out a replacement right away. If the replacement doesn't have any issues, I will keep the 5 stars and assume i got one with a glitch. It happens. If there are still issues, then it will be an overall problem and my ratings will drop. There was a person on the forum page that also had this problem. Most others are reporting no issues with the battery. So for now, I will gave Amazon the benefit of the doubt.I have only had this for a day so I have not explored everything. This is my first tablet so I have little to compare it to, but I have a Kindle e-reader which I love. I found this to be pretty user friendly considering I don't even have a smartphone so apps and touchscreens are new to me. I found the user's guide to me helpful as well as the Kindle forum to answer questions I didn't feel like looking for answers to. I had no problem uploading my favorite sites. Some said they couldn't watch movies but I have been able to with both Netflix and Amazon on demand.Also, I guess there were some issues with the sound in the first generation Fire. I didn't have any problems, I didn't even need to use full volume when watching shows.I downloaded a few free apps to play around with. And of course my books. I like that I can download some to the Fire but if there is one I want to read that I already own, I can download it from kindle Cloud. I can read books without downloading them via the Cloud but that means keeping the wireless on. Same with music.I'm not to great with touchscreens and I loathe fingerprints so I prefer to use the stylus that I got separately. I didn't get a charger (it comes with USB cord only but charging through the computer won't really work), the one for my Kindle fits but doesn't charge as fast. So I ended up ordering the fast charger as the Fire isn't meant to last as many hours as the Kindle e-reader. But I still think the battery life is pretty good.I like reading on this, I thought the back-light would bother me, but I can adjust the brightness. I actually prefer reading in the portrait mode as it shows two pages and looks like a book page would.So far I am very happy with this, my third Kindle device. I like Amazon and find them to be very user friendly when I need help so I have no concerns so far. If there are any issues, I will update my review because I take spending my money very seriously.
Reviews.Title: I really like it. Update: not holding charge

Reviews.Author: P. Ip "16ue"
Reviews.Content: This review is on the Amazon Kindle Fire HD 8.9 32GB as I got it on November 18, Saturday and I got three days to play with it before writing this review.This is my first Kindle device.  Prior to this, I use Kindle apps on my other three tablets, a Viewsonic gTablet (10" screen), a Lenovo A1 (7" screen), and a Nexus 7 (7" screen), and my cell phone, a Samsung Galaxy S3, and Roku for the movie streaming.  Since I am a Prime user, getting a Kindle device should provide an even better user experience for Prime Instant Videos, and I am not disappointed.  All Amazon contents displayed very well with this device, especially HD movies.  The sound is amazing but does appear less direct as the speakers are facing backward.  A few times, I found my hands holding the device were covering the speaker ports and muting the sound but I realized that immediately and changed my holding position.  All Amazon contents are well integrated with the Fire HD so I do not need to start an app for book reading and another app to watch movies.  Just click on the content, which lives on a carousel at the home screen, and the Fire HD will start the appropriate app.  The Fire HD supports the 5 GHz band of 802.11n and works with hidden SSID and MAC address access control.  My connection speed is at 130Mbps when connected to a Netgear router.  During the playback of a HD movie, however, my video player abruptly ended three times with network connection errors, even though the network connection icon was still showing on the notification bar.  Only a shut-down and a restart would fix the interruptions.  Except for that movie, I did not experience any interruptions when I watched two more movies in HD.  The viewing experience was excellent and the best among all my portable devices.  The resolution of the screen is just amazing.  I did see some backlight breeding from the top left corner of the screen when held in landscape mode, as I was turning on the device.  I have yet to contact Amazon to see if this is considered a defect.  Other feature that I did not test but intend to is to borrow a book.Overall, I give this unit four stars.  I took half a star off because of the lack of apps.  Since Fire HD requires the use of the Amazon app store, it is not as comprehensive as the Google Play store.  Not all Android apps will work.  In particular, most Google apps will not.  I have always used Google Currents to provide news feeds on my other Android devices but when I side-loaded Google Currents, the app would not start.  The best way to test side-loading apps is to load TapPouch Lite on the Fire HD if you have another Android device.  Then you can use TapPouch Lite on the other Android device to share the apps.  I used TapPouch Lite to share Mobo player and MyBackup Pro.  Interestingly, I purchased MyBackup Pro from the Amazon app store, but somehow it was deemed not compatible with the Fire HD 8.9.  It actually works, albeit some part of the app displays with a smaller screen.I took another half star off because the default input method cannot be changed or supplemented.  The default keyboard misses key presses from time to time and it is not very smart in making predictions.  Unlike other Android devices, however, the input method on Fire HD is deeply integrated and I cannot install other input method editors (IME) such as Chinese or other keyboards such as Swiftkey.  Immediately this limited the use of Kindle HD for someone like me who uses more than the default languages that the tablet will support.  I will not be able to input in another language such as Chinese to search or communicate through email.In summary, it is an awesome device for viewing Amazon contents.  It falls a little short as an all-purpose tablet and I hope Amazon will be able to remedy some of its shortcomings through future updates.Update (11/29/2012)I contacted Amazon customer service regarding the backlight breeding from one of the corners of the tablet and Amazon shipped me a brand new replacement, which I received two days ago.  I am happy to report that the new tablet is perfect without the backlight bleeding issue.  In addition, I found that it stayed connected to my 802.11n access point throughout an entire movie, something that my original tablet struggled to do and had been disconnecting multiple times during movie playing.  Way to go, Amazon.  This is really excellent customer service and the replacement process was absolutely painless.
Reviews.Title: Fire HD 8.9 32GB: An awesome device for viewing Amazon contents

Reviews.Author: Travel mavn "luvsbooks"
Reviews.Content: I have had a couple of days to work with the kindle fire and I have to say I'm delighted. Maybe reading all the reviews lowered all my expectations but I absolutely love it. I realize some may have real mechanical issues but mine has worked flawlessly.I have a smart phone so was already familiar with using the touch screen, which at least on my Fire is very responsive (as much as my 4g phone is or better; especially with internet pages).I tend to obsessively read reviews on Amazon and googled using the Kindle fire review search term so no surprises about no charger (which I had already bought discounted when I bought the fire, and I thought they made fairly clear that it was not included) and I did cave and buy the seriously overpriced cover. I don't hate the cover but definitely not a $55 dollar item; works as described and looks ok and it saved me any issues with the on and off button people seem to be having since the open/on shut/off works great. I had also purchased a stylus that is great; only thing I need to figure out is how to find a way to keep the stylus attached to the case so I don't keep misplacing it.I also did search around and borrowed the Kindle fire users guide by Shelby Johnson which saved me alot of the frustration I have been hearing in the reviews. I would never have figured out how to get Google Chrome working and picked up a few of the recommended app's which I love (HD battery one especially nice as far as splitting out how much time available depending on what you are using the tablet for ie internet search, movie etc)and knew basically how to navigate; although I thought it was fairly simple as far as the carousel/top terms that take me to the different areas (video/apps/music) I rather like the whole setup actually and like the look so setting my own backdrop isn't important to me and I actually don't find the ad's intrusive.So, my basic needs for the tablet were for magazines as I was getting tired of bulky paper, movies downloaded so when I travel I can watch without lugging out the laptop or needing wireless, netflix and Hulu plus along with Amazon prime are my standard television watching even at home (no cable) so wanted to be sure these worked well and internet - usually I just use for searches, facebook.I bought the 32gb since I knew I was going to have movies downloaded.  So far internet working great, there are alot of tabs but nothing too annoying and still getting a feel for searches but no problems.Movies- bought and downloaded off amazon prime effortlessly using the black friday deals to pick up some I don't own yet; I'll try the downloading of some I own when I have more time.My music (limited amount on Amazon cloud since most on itunes; we'll have to see about transferring some of those) downloaded easily so I have music at any time and the sound is great.Netflix and Hulu plus (apps) worked great and seem pretty seamless; I do have high speed at home since I work online and my primary television is all streaming so that may effect them but they work as well on tablet as TV.Downloaded a couple of simple games since it isn't something I do alot of and they run fast and look beautiful (star wars angry birds, temple, Mah Jongg they look fantastic.Magazines I am very pleased with. I decided to try Oprah, More, Smithsonian and Natl Geographic and they all are working perfectly.  Still need to play with them to decide which I need to keep but they turn like a magazine using swipe then with a double tap expand to read in text, another tap and back to small so pictures and ad's can be viewed like thumbing through a magazine.  Nat'l geographic links directly to video's which is fun.  So far still only a basic use of them but no glitches so far.I didn't try the facebook app after reading reviews but it pulls up perfectly on the internet. The only thing to play with is to try again to download dolphin and flash (the kindle book does give links to do this but it was the only one I couldn't pull up immediately; or at least I don't think they downloaded)So still a learning curve but in the two days I've had the fire I've loved it. I was afraid since I had a 4g phone it would be a waste but the size is perfect for magazines and movies (a bit too heavy to use as a daily reading device, so keeping the paperwhite also for nighttime reading) but it is something I will definitely use every day.It would be perfect if I could download the pictures off my camera on vacation and manipulate directly. I wouldn't even bring the laptop in that case, I think that is the only thing for my basic needs that requires anything above the Kindle Fire.May have received a lucky Kindle with no mechanical issues but loving it. Looks like it will be worth every penny.  I do use Ipod and alot of my music is on that but I am heavily into kindle books and amazon content so this tablet works great for me; glad I got it and not a ipad. I also realize I have already been trained by my previous devices so the learning curve wasn't too great as far as navigating touch screen. Seamless so far.
Reviews.Title: Does everything I expected on a tablet, very pleased

Reviews.Author: Comdet
Reviews.Content: As with the original Fire, the out of box experience is very nicely done. Very straightforward process of just turning it on and letting the tablet register and update itself. It took about 10 minutes (with the majority of the time waiting for an update to download) and it was ready to go. It picked up all my original Fire music and books from the cloud and most of my Fire apps. I was disappointed to see that a couple of my favorite apps (TED Talks and Play Music Videos Free) were judged not compatible with my new Fire. Hopefully updates will be coming soon.The screen is delightful! Crisp and clear, and a marked increase in resolution versus the original Fire. Videos on the HD Fire are simply amazing.The sound quality is also a marked improvement. While it was pretty much mandatory to hook up an external speaker for the original Fire, the new Fire puts out pretty decent sound quality all on its own. I still hook it up to external speakers (I'm partial to the Bose Companion 20) for movies and music when I'm at my desk, but it puts out more than adequate sound all on its own.Response time is more snappy than the original Fire, and the carousel is easier to navigate (smoother scrolling). Picking up a WiFi signal seems to be better with the new fire - I'm getting all signal strength bars displayed in areas of the house where I could only get 2 or 3 bars with the original Fire.The form factor is great for video watching. The extra screen size makes a big difference. The other huge advantage to the size is typing. It's MUCH easier to see and use the onscreen keyboard than on the original Fire. I had no problems typing without a stylus; on the original Fire a stylus is a must.So far I don't see many misses other than a hard-to-find power button. The casing and build quality is not at the same level as an iPad, but neither is the price. I'm very pleased with the price-performance level of the HD Fire.This is not replacing my original Fire - I'll continue to use that for most of my book reading and when I need portability. For everything else, the larger screen is well worth the additional cost.I have a Nexus 7, the iPad 2 and an HP Touchpad and the Fire is my favorite by far. Not because either the original or this new Fire are the best in terms of build quality or speed or tech specs, but for one simple reason: the Fire makes it so incredibly easy to avail myself of entertainment and content. The tight link to the Amazon ecosystem is, for me, a huge plus - it keeps my entertainment pipeline full of things I want to read, listen to or watch with little or no effort on my part. And, best of all, a lot of that content is free through Prime.Love it, and highly recommend.
Reviews.Title: A real big fork for the content buffet!

Reviews.Author: Frances M. Tuttle
Reviews.Content: First, I don't understand reviews/reviewers who waste time criticizing what isn't there - what is the point of that?  Read the product specifications and you won't be disappointed.  It is no secret that the Fires were created for the Amazon eco-system.Second, Amazon has always said that the Kindle Fires were all about consumption of Amazon products - in fact, that's why I bought the original Kindle e-reader, Kindle Fire, Kindle Fire HD 7" (which I only used for a month and half before I knew I would want an 8.9) and now Kindle Fire HD 8.9" - I am a mass consumer of Kindle books and now videos with my Amazon Prime membership.Third, my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" is not an iPad replacement - nor was it created to be one.  I watch videos, play games (and yes, there are a few games that do not play on the HD 8.9 - but that happens with computers - get over it)and read books and magazines - that's what it was created for.  My magazines are incredible on the 8.9 - a great leap over the 7.  Stop comparing it to an iPad, please! And I hate to break it to you iPad fans out there - but you do realize that an iPad is in no way a laptop replacement, don't you?  Don't try to compare apples to oranges.  And no, the camera was not meant to take pictures - isn't it meant to be a Skype thing?Fourth, shut the wifi off when you are not using it - it helps with the battery life.  I have to charge my iPhone (yes, I have an iPhone) at least once a day because I use it so much, so having to recharge my Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is no big deal for me - it comes with the territory.  My original Kindle e-reader did, indeed, last for weeks on one charge, but it wasn't a computer being used for many things - so if anyone buys a tablet with the expectation of long battery life, you are, indeed, going to be disappointed.Fifth, for the money I think the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is an excellent product.  The display is gorgeous, the sound is excellent with the new external speakers (on my original Fire I had to download an app to pump up the volume because I could hardly hear it without headphones) and the wifi connection is much quicker than on previous versions.  The Silk browser - well I find most tablet browsers to be kind of sucky compared to my laptop - so that is a non-issue for me.In summary, if you are looking for a device to watch videos (both Amazon Prime and Netflix in my case), read your Kindle books (and no, you won't be able to read your books on a bright, sunny day on this device - but I would hope you would realize that before you buy), read mazagines and play games, this is a device for you.  Would it be nice if it came with a charger?  Sure, and maybe Amazon will begin to include them in future versions, but for now, this is exactly the device I wanted and it is exactly what I expected.P.S.  I have originall purchased one of the really expensive cases to use with my 8.9, but I returned it and ordered a Fintie slim-fit case and find it to be absolutely perfect.Enjoy your 8.9 - I know I am!
Reviews.Title: LOVE IT ... KINDLE FIRE HD 8.9 DOES EXACTLY WHAT I EXPECTED

Reviews.Author: Bill Hansen "Bill Hansen"
Reviews.Content: This was originally written for another forum, in response to a person who worried that the Kindle would be too difficult to use, and too strictly limited to the Kindle environment. As a much older person and a technophobe, I worried about those things too - but the Kindle Fire and its siblings are far easier to use, for more powerful and flexible, than I had imagined. Users are not limited to Amazon content at all.In the 36 hours I've had my 8.9 I've subscribed to the National Geographic magazine (gorgeous!!), read the New York Times in a format which looks indentical to the one I'd buy at a newstand, watched a few short instructional videos, read a short e-book, checked our local weather using the very detailed Weather Channel app which comes with the Kindle, perused the CNN news site, checked my Gmail account several times and have written a few emails on the Kindle, discovered that my Google Calendar and all my Gmail contacts were automatically downloaded to the Kindle, purchased several small items - you get the idea. I could have bought movies, shopped for trousers, cameras, sticky buns, software (almost any sort of software)...... You get the idea. I'm a very non-technical person, 78 years old*, using my very first tablet for just 36 hours. I didn't sweat one drop doing all that. The Kindle is set up so beautifully that it almost does it all for you.Sideloading (this was a question someone had asked) - That's a process whereby a Kindle user can download apps which the Kindle app store doesn't offer. It involves getting the "apk file" for the app (similar to the ".exe" file for any other computer application) from a site which lists them, saving the apk file to the computer, moving it to the Kindle, and installing it. You do have to have another Android device available, one time only, to begin the process - so if you don't have an Android cell phone, for example, borrow one for an hour or so, from a friend or acquaintance (or ask locally on Craigslist, your health club or church, etc).Yes, there are several steps involved in sideloading. But you can't possibly damage your Kindle, and you don't void your warranty. I've had a an android cell phone for over two years, and there are a few things - a little thing called Weather Bug, a hiking app called My Tracks, a wonderful MP3 player called Power Amp, and Google Maps - all of which are available in the main Google Play Store, but none of which are available in the Android version of the Play Store. One by one, I'll go through that "sideloading" procedure to get them on the Kindle 8.9. I have the 4G version of the 8.9, so the hiking and mapping apps might be available. If not, I'll just have to continue using them on my cell phone.Applications like Google Maps, GPS, and the hiking app won't work unless you have the $G version of the Kindle, but many other applications will work just fine. Some games are not yet optimized for the HD screen.Portability - if you're using the tablet almost exclusively in your home, get one with a 10 inch screen. Google makes one, but there are better 10 inchers out there - iPad (boooo!!!) and Asus Transformer 700 have the best screens, and the Asus has a micro SD card slot which is a very nice thing to have. The Samsung Galaxy 10.1 comes very close behind. Any one of those - and also the 8.9 - can be paired with a very light "blue tooth" keyboard, or docked to the keyboard, for those times when you're going to do extensive writing. For short notes and emails, the "virtual keyboard" of the 8.9 is perfectly fine, but the virtual keyboard on a 10 inch tablet would be better. The 10 inch screen would be better for watching videos or movies, or for reading photo-heavy magazines like the National Geographic - but lots of people are delighted with video, photos, and graphics on the 7 and 9 inch screens.However, if you think you'd like to take the tablet along on trips or carry it around town, the more compact 8.9 inch size is much better. It's also better for reading books, because it's easy to hold in your hand. Don't let anyone tell you the 8.9 is too big or too heavy to hold. It's not.Portability - I already covered that. I got my 8.9 because it will be primarily a reading tool for books, newspapers, and magazines - but the darn thing is so adaptable that it can do just about anything I'd want."Toooo much information" as folks say. Hope it helps.Bill Hansen*did I mention how wonderful it is, for these old eyes, to be able to change the size of text as you read?
Reviews.Title: Amazingly adaptable and easy to use

Reviews.Author: shelly
Reviews.Content: So let me start off by saying that Amazon has done it again,I just don't get all the negative reviews about the charger not coming with it, well Amazon has always been up front about that.I am not going to go into the techincal side of that because there are many great reviews that cover this. This is my 3rd Kindle, I have the Kindle keyboard which I really love for reading and using my Audible books on and very lightweight to carry around. I have the original Kindle fire which fell in love with but did run out of space very quickly, my grandaughter is getting this one for Christmas. So before purchasing the Kindle fire Hd 8.9" with 64gb, I did do many searches and reviews to try and determine which tablet was going to be right for me. I did choose this one because of the service that Amazon does provide, which is top notch, I am a prime member and Amazon does its best to provide great service.I was surprised that most all the Apps that I had on the original fire were able to be downloaded to the new one. I haven't had a chance to use the mobile plan yet because of the wireless so far. The people who have complained about the adds, well what can I say, it is really not a big deal, you see them on any smartphone now adays, I personally would not pay the extra to have them removed as they don't bother the way the tablet works. The only thing that I have noticed so far is the on/off button, it is hard to find but I have an Otterbox for a case and this does help to find it better, by the way Otterbox is the only protection to use for your smartphones or Kindles but that is another review. I hope this was helpfull to anyone that is trying to decide, if you are familiar with Amazon and prime this would be a great tablet for you.
Reviews.Title: Amazon did do it again!

Reviews.Author: L. Patterson "graphic designer"
Reviews.Content: I am "reviewing" the Fire HD 8.9" with 4G LTE. IT'S WONDERFUL!!!!! I just want to agree with everything stated by reviewer Michael Gallagher. I am not a tech person, just a little old lady who loved her old $79.00 Kindle and whose very generous husband wanted to give her a boffo Christmas gift! Lucky me because this Kindle is just beautiful in design, operation and picture and sound quality...I like it much more than the kid's IPads - the picture quality is sharper, color more vibrant and sound is tons better. The keypad works great, too, it's huge.Downloading fun stuff is almost instantaneous and I was up and running in a few seconds with all my news apps;  NPR and PBS, my magazines, Smithsonian and Atlantic Monthly, which I LOVE and all my books which are stored along with everything else I've purchased bookwise over the years in the Cloud!!! As a long-standing 3 Stooges fan, I downloaded several episodes of that and was so glad to be able to a.) have any available and b.) have a GREAT selection. The playback is gorgeous and the sound is wonderful!!!People say that the Fires HD are for Kindle content like that's a bad thing...I don't know why? I get my Netflix, all the apps I love, any TV show or motion picture ever made, all the music in the world, email, Office Suite, Skype, and .pdfs, add my iPhone and what more do you need???This is a real case of seeing IS believing and I wouldn't trade my Kindle Fire HD for ANYTHING!!!
Reviews.Title: I wouldn't be without it for even a day!!!!

Reviews.Author: Bill in Idaho
Reviews.Content: I have been using an iPad for many years and I have loved them.  I bought a 7" Kindle Fire HD first and a week later I purchased the 8.9".  This is not an all inclusive review but I wanted to share my perspective.Positives:1.) I am impressed!  I love the quality of sound that comes from the 2 Dolby speakers.  I think this is one aspect that the iPad does not have for me.2.) The quality of the display is very good.  I compared it to the iPad and I did not see any difference in my opinion.3.) Another selling point is the speed of the WIFI which makes streaming videos fast and enjoyable.4.) Lighter than the iPad and I liked the ability to easily hold on to the Kindle Fire (both 7" and 8.9") when compared to the iPads.  I like the ability to hold on to the Kindle Fires and not having them slip out of my hands (like the iPad did).5.) Lower price than the iPad. I could afford both of my Kindles for slightly more than the cost of one iPad.Negatives:1.) Lack of camera on the back. But this is not a huge issue for me.2.) The ads that come on the screens and that you have to pay to have them removed.3.) PowerFast charger was not included in the purchase.  I purchased my Kindle Fires at a local store and because I did so...I did not receive any discount for purchasing the PowerFast Charger.  I think Amazon should provide you with a discount even if you purchase from a local store.  This discount could even be provided to you online that can be used for credit for apps, music or books.  Just an idea.Conclusion:I have been enjoying my Kindle Fires!  The Kindle Fire receives 5 stars from me because I was totally impressed by the quality of Dolby Speakers and the quality of display. The negatives would not prevent me from purchasing another Kindle but I would like Amazon to know how cheesy those ads are.  I am impressed with the speed of how the PowerFast charger works!  My Kindle Fires are thin, easy to hold and provide a positive experience reading books as well as watching videos.  The cost made a big difference to me as well.  Quality for a lower price is important in today's economy!  I hope that Amazon reads these reviews and takes note of the negative aspects (followed by improvements).  As of right now I would be very willing to buy more Kindles in the future.  You can't go wrong with a Kindle Fire purchase!
Reviews.Title: An iPad convert...Kindle Fire is awesome

Reviews.Author: C. Steed "singer man"
Reviews.Content: This screen is AMAZING!!! Every time I look at it, I'm more impressed.I have the first Fire,love it,used it all the time and I did more than use it for media content.Now that I have the HD 8.9, the media experience is enhanced and so is everything else. I'm not worried about the flash no longer being used for newer android devices. If it's that big of a deal, then just side load Flash,anyone can do it.Some complained about dropbox not being in the apps. Again just side load it and it works fine. Basically you can just about get any android app you want through side loading them or rooting your device. Plenty of videos out there to show you how. But I will say if you want to root it there are techies that can do it for you if you're concerned about making a mistake and it doesn't cost much at all. So you can get a full android experience with this tablet, many did with the first fire.Ipad is a good device but this one is no push over. Whatever you want to do on it, there is a way to do it.The only thing that could hinder you is if you don't get the LTE version so you can have data.Then you have to rely on wi-fi(which by the way on this device is amazing.)I had the Samsung Note 10.1 and the wi-fi struggled. My old fire was picking up signal better than that $500 tablet.You can take care of business work and entertain yourself with this device so don't let the complaints turn you away. I went to best buy and while I was there I heard some one who works there telling some people who were interested in the Fire HD not to get it if they wanted something for business purposes.He said it was only good for reading books. Clearly he spent no time with this device.I don't have to tell you what he recommended.Overall this is a great device. Just get it and feel it in your hands and turn on the screen.Also remember anything made by man can malfunction and when you deliver stuff in high volume,some one can easily get a bad one.It happens with every company, even apple. This tablet is great!Wow I must say that they didn't lie about the better wi-fi! I'm picking up signals in areas I never did with the first fire or the other more expensive tabs. I'm liking this!
Reviews.Title: Not  as limited as some say

Reviews.Author: SMM "Leogirl817"
Reviews.Content: So I've had the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 for 4 days.  Here are my reviews on this tablet:Positive:Outstanding HD Screen - Perfect size tablet, Not too big, not too smallGames - Fast and quick downloads, larger screen makes games easier and better to playBooks - Easier to read on larger screen, excellent lightingMusic - Excellent Dolby soundVideos - Outstanding, like watching a mini HDTV with surrond soundEmails - Background makes email easier to read than the original Kindle FireSilk - Fast BrowingNegatives:No Charger Light - No big deal, I have the iPhone so I can get used to not having a charger light.Tablet smudges very easily.  Screen protector and protective case is definately recommended.Magazines do not fill screen in portrait postion.Scrolling the carousel in the portrait postion shows other apps at the bottom that "Customers Also Bought".  I find this annoying, don't care what other customers bought.  Wish there was a way to get rid of this.This this a great tablet, not perfect, no tablet out there is perfect, not even the iPad (both my kids have iPads) but it fits my lifestyle when I want to unwind.
Reviews.Title: Very Impressed

Reviews.Author: Herb "Herb Stiles"
Reviews.Content: I love my Kindle Fire 8.9 HD. I've owned a Fire since they came out and have willed it to my daughter. The new 8.9 Fire has taken care of all the problems I had with the old Fire - Mainly the size and the camera.  The size allows me to read my magazines with ease and the camera allows me to use the Skype APP.  I'm 65 and like to watch movies, read my newspapers, listen to music and audio books. Its the perfect device for all that and is simple to use. When I have to access the net it I get to my site quickly.  It does everthing I want and I love it.
Reviews.Title: I love my Kindle Fire 8.9 HD

Reviews.Author: onehundredyearsold
Reviews.Content: I purchased the fire 8.9 as an entertainment system. I wasn't upset at all about being "locked in" to buying content from Amazon, I'd be doing that anyway. Can't beat Amazon for selection or service.The sound and picture are superb. Crisp picture and surprisingly good (almost) surround sound. Watching movies from Amazon is outstanding.Love reading my books on it. Some books should be paper but for most books the Kindle gives more features than paper ever can. It is nice to be able to get word definitions while still on the page you're reading. I like the x-ray feature too.Battery life is fabulous. I can use it for hours and hours between recharges. Internet connection is fast and reliable. The size is good for holding to read or watching shows. It is not so heavy that one tires of holding it too soon.However, not all the features of the fire are equally a success.The Silk browser is poor in features,functionality and performance. Silk tends to crash at least hourly (frequently more often). It's constantly saying whatever page I'm on has stopped responding and would I like the page restored. How could the developers have missed that? Why is there no word about an intent to remedy this constant failure of a basic web browser. Since I bought this for entertainment, I'm feeling less entertained and more annoyed.The typing feature is glitchy.  It frequently misses the first letter typed while compensating you for this problem by giving you double of the next letter you type. Space bar is inexplicably flaky.Some of the applications I've purchased though they were listed as compatible, crash.For this being their flagship Kindle product they should be ashamed to have let this be distributed with flaws that could have been fixed. Now that it is out I'm afraid they will not feel an obligation to improve the interface and functionality but instead will play hot potato, with the consumers holding their potato Kindles. Perhaps they should have named it the Kindle Crash.But possibly I am wrong and Amazon is working to improve it's product. I do have to say I have always received excellent service from Amazon and perhaps it will carry over to the Kindle Fire as well.Update May 29,2013No significant updates to resolve issues. So tired of having to make compromises, especially with the browser. I almost feel like they realize it's beyond repair. I will be buying a different tablet,probably an iPad. Definitely NOT a Kindle anything ever again.
Reviews.Title: Good concept, so-so execution. Browser is the WORST!

Reviews.Author: Matthew J. Haslett "Kindle lover!"
Reviews.Content: I am a long time lover of all things Kindle, just to put that out there.  So yes, perhaps I am a bit biased due to having an extensive Kindle library, but nonetheless, I can say with as much objectivity as I can muster: this is a wonderful device that I would not hesitate recommending to someone.  And please know, I've been around for a few years now and I have learned to *NOT* recommend things to people, or at least some people, because inevitably something will go wrong and *YOU* will now become the focus of their displeasure.  So, for me to recommend this is a definite leap of faith. :)There are plenty of excellent in-depth reviews so I will not rehash them.  Suffice it to say that Amazon did a great job with this device and I am more than pleased with it.The screen is beautiful, the sound is very nice and loud, it performs very well, and the interface is much improved over the previous generation Fire, which we also owned and liked.  This is truly much closer to the iPad in terms of functionality and performance in my opinion.  And once you factor in pricing?  I have no idea what, after reading up on the iPad, what it could possibly do to warrant the price premium, I honestly don't.  And please don't think that I'm just simply bashing Apple, because we own various iPod variants and an iPhone 5.  Android devices do outnumber Apple devices in our house, but Apple is still represented and I have to say, the new Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is a definite winner.  If we had the resources there'd be one under the xmas tree of all of our relatives this year. :)To quickly address reading (what Kindle was originally all about!!) I still prefer an e-ink version to read on, and currently I'm using the Kindle Paperwhite and I absolutely love the screen, it is simply amazing.  The light is there when you need/want it and it is a joy to read on, no eye fatigue (at least no more than reading a paper book).  Reading on the Kindle Fire is nice though, the dictionary is exceptionally quick and the responsiveness of the Fire will always be quicker than that of its e-ink siblings, but that's just the nature of the involved technology, not a knock to e-ink, just a kudos to the Fire for being a fast device.  It is definitely nice to read on and I have, all I'm saying is that for lengthy periods of reading I prefer the e-ink, but there's nothing wrong with the experience on a Fire.And just to quickly address the griping about a charger not being included with the device: Amazon is leading the way with this.  How many devices do you own that use a micro-USB charger?  Quite a few I'd imagine.  Why on earth should Amazon add to the per-unit cost by including something that isn't 'truly' necessary nowadays?  I'm very happy to pay a little bit less for something than to have yet another charger laying around.  Yes, it does charge faster with a somewhat non-traditional charging rate of 1.8A, but still, I am all for overall reduced costs and a 'greener' product.  And I think that they make it quite clear that the charger is not included, so for those that complain about it, well, they probably complain about a lot of stuff in life if they pay that little attention to things - everything is everyone else's fault, not theirs, lol.Good luck and please, if you're thinking about it, take the plunge, you'll love your device.
Reviews.Title: Excellent tablet!!  BEAUTIFUL HD screen, great sound, 'snappy' processing!

Reviews.Author: Viki
Reviews.Content: I saved for a year to buy this and am VERY disappointed.  The first one they shipped me wouldn't stay on longer than 30 seconed.  The second wouldn't connect to WI-FI until I purchased a new wireless modem at my house.  My old Kindle (one of the earlier versions) connects anywhere, but this one will only work within 12 feet of my modem at home.  $300 down the drain.  So disappointed.
Reviews.Title: Very Disappointed

Reviews.Author: Nick S "Nick S"
Reviews.Content: Cons:I'm a medical doctor, and I bought the Kindle Fire because I was planning on using it to download my PDF format medical books. Although I am able to view the books, I'm unable to search or highlight the books. It's pointless to have a 500-1000 page reference that you can't search. The only way to get these options is to email the file to an Amazon email that they create for you. It will convert the file to the Kindle format for an outrageous fee per Megabit (~$.99) if it is under 50MB. If its more than 50MB you're shit out of luck.I have literally spent the whole day and night, researching this and talking to customer service by email and on the phone just to end up feeling frustrated and disappointed. I had to explain the same thing 3-5 times over to the customer service rep, there was some kind of language barrier with this foreign based help I received.I've wasted my time and money on this device for the purpose I bought it for. The whole thing is set up to keep pumping money into Amazon by forcing you to pay money for every little thing.They want you to buy a yearly subscription to Amazon Prime and then they say you get to watch free movies, get to share books, and get free two day shipping...how is it free if you're paying a yearly subscription???Also, I initially had problems with the Netflix and Pandora apps. It said they were downloaded but they didn't show up in my Apps folder. So I tried re-downloading them and it wouldn't let me because it said they were already downloaded. I emailed customer service multiple times giving them the specifics of my problem and they kept sending me the same generic email that didn't help at all.This device would be nice if you were only planning and buying everything you downloaded through Amazon. Its not as compatible with other document formats as it says it is.PROS:Nice screen and speakers along with fast WiFi.
Reviews.Title: Disappointed- Don't buy if you have large PDF format books

Reviews.Author: lady_koenig
Reviews.Content: I loved the Kindle Fire 7" and was very excited to receive my 8.9" model. I am so disappointed I could cry.-) The battery will not hold a charge - one hour Max. I need to sit where there is an electrical outlet so I can plug in. It was plugged in overnight and did not fully charge.-) With the 7" I could scroll through dozens and dozens of posts on Facebook. With the 8.9" it will load what you first see on the screen, if you try to scroll you get the little circular icon that just continues to search. I have waited for 15 minutes and it never goes further even though I have 5 bars on the internet strength. By then the battery is drained from constant search. I give up and get out the 7" Fire.-) Touch screen is unresponsive. I have to keep an eye on what I type - I have 2 problems there. First, when I type many times the letters do not appear as typed and I may have to hit the key several times before the letter will appear. Second, The space bar when typing does not put in spaces. I will look up at screen and see just a mass of letters. I will have to scan the typed mass and attempt to put the curser at the appropriate place and hit the space bar until a space is added.I had read the reviews and felt the 8.9" had all the features and size I wanted. I come to the conculsion that I just got a lemon and will be returning it and looking at another brand of tablet. With this sad piece of electronics Amazon has lost one customer. How could they have gone from such a nice tablet as the 7" is to a piece of junk that I received in this 8.9" model? HD is fine if you just want to read your e-mail or view photos but that is not what I wanted this tablet for. I was hoping to get what it appears that most of reviews received. That is not what I received. I am taking my 7" Fire off the eBay listing and using it until I can get a better tablet at my local electronic store.I would not recommend this tablet to anybody. I am typing this review on my laptop since typing is one thing I can not do with the 8.9" tablet.
Reviews.Title: Very disappointed - Loved 7" - Where to start with problems of 8.9"

Reviews.Author: mbw
Reviews.Content: Of course a very early review, I've had my 32GB Fire HD (FHD) less than 24 hours, but what a difference over my Kindle Fire!Some of the pros:-the size is just right-the borders are big enough to hold onto without activating something on the screen-the color and resolution are stunning-the speed is an order of magnitude better than the Fire-connectivity is flawless to my wifi node-sound is actually 'stereo like' (from the front only) but more realistic than the older Fire, if still on the hollow side.In reality, this pad is better than my computer at work when it comes to streaming video like IMDb, YouTube, or Amazon Prime videos, (at the end of a long day when the work's done :). There are just no breaks or pauses.Another thing I've noticed is that this FHD model doesn't 'hang' like the older Fire did between tasks or websites. The new processor must have fixed these bugs.The interface is only slightly different from the original Fire and probably won't take me more than a couple hours to get used to. The scrolling images seem to have a bit more flare on the larger screen, but I've always prefered them over other interfaces like my daughters Nook.  I've noticed a star for accessing favorites in the lower right hand corner of the screen which I find very handy.  And the device tools are now a pull down....ok, that works.  Please Note!  If you buy this with 'Special Offers', you are forced to endure advertisements when you first turn it on, but it's $15 lower in price over a similar unit without 'Special Offers'.  Wow did I get tired of those ads real quick.  Not to worry....I was able to turn them off.....by paying the extra $15 difference in price! (you can do this after registration).I have played around a little with the built in camera, but from what I've seen, the resolution is low.  Skype is a nice feature but I haven't had an opportunity to try it out.So in short, they seem to have fixed all the shortcomings I found in the first standard Fire, improved the useability alot, and added some interesting features. I find this pad much more pleasurable to use and a worthy upgrade. I've handed my Fire over to someone non-techy but very near and dear and she is very happy...I'm mean, she got it for free so why wouldn't she be?  Which raises a point; the register and deregister process was a breeze. All my content transfered right over, (with the exception of some low-def game apps which I don't miss). If you want help, pls comment. I'd be happy to walk you through it.This case Amazon Kindle Fire HD 8.9" Standing Leather Case, Onyx Black (will only fit Kindle Fire HD 8.9") also comes highly recommended though on the expensive side, (please see my review).
Reviews.Title: Very nice indeed, and a worthy upgrade to the first Fire

Reviews.Author: biker boy 66 "biker boy"
Reviews.Content: First let me state that I am no expert on Tablets,I don't know anything about all of the technical details that I read on some of the reviews ,I have better things to do than play with my toys all day, and nitpick this tablet to death , but I think that the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is AWSOME, it does everything that I ask it to do and more, picture is perfect, set up was easy. I LOVE IT. For the money , I don't think you can get a better deal on a Tablet, than this Kindle Fire HD 8.9. Thank you for reading my review.
Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9

Reviews.Author: L. Hill
Reviews.Content: This larger Fire is exactly what I was looking for.  It fulfills ALL the needs I had for a tablet device - by which I am saying, make sure you KNOW what you need!I purchased the Gen1 Fire last year about a day after it was released.  I have used that one for a multitude of tasks - reading, watching video content, staying connected to email (and replying, but not generating new emails), and most of all as a "replacement" for paper documents I generated for use in teaching and preaching.  This was the MAIN use of my Gen1 Fire...but the screen was just too small.Thus - when the 8.9" was released, I ordered within 5 minutes of it posting on Amazon!  Wasn't going to wait this time - went with one day shipping too!  Then the wait...and the early receipt - that rocked!  I received my new Fire (hence named Dad's Bonfire to differentiate from the Gen1) about a week earlier than I anticipated, and immediately put it to work!  It was exactly as I expected - no disappointments.- Large, clear screen - allows me to create documents on desktop in 12point type, on a modified page (9.5" x 5.5" custom page size) that fits the width of the screen perfectly.  I save these documents in PDF format to "fix" the pages and limit reformatting.  At 12point, with this size screen, my lessons and sermons are perfectly sized to see from a lecturn or pulpit as I teach.- Apps - as I am not into a lot of games (ok...Angry Birds...who isn't) - the apps I already had for the Gen1 also worked on my Bonfire.  The "paid" apps (those I didn't grab for free in the past year) all transported as well - Calengoo, Evernote, Whiteboard, EasyPrint, Pulse, K-9 Mail, OfficesuitePro, Sketchbook Mobile, Proclaim Remote, Logos - all worked with no modifications on the new Bonfire.  Because the 8.9" uses a modified Android 4.1, most open even more functionality.- Carousel - still not a fan...I actually liked the "Favorites Bookshelf" from the Gen 1 better.  However, the carousel is smoother now, and more reactive than on the Gen1.  I have not had the problem of earlier reviewers of the carousel "populating" with everything.  I am not really a fan of how Favorites are now handled on the 8.9" - it is as if they are pushing you to use the carousel...it is a neat idea, but not really for me.- Sound - have to say...wow!  Compared to other "fruit" models - the dual speaker setup on the Fire is much superior.- HDMI out - I have streamed Amazon content from the Fire to my big screen tv...very nice.- Web - one area that still needs work.  I am not a fan of the Silk browser...am looking at moving to a side-loaded app...no matter what they say, it is slower than others, and seems to push you towards what THEY want...limited ability to customize the "starter" page - you get your most visited, then two rows - trending now, and selected sites - both selected, apparently, by Amazon...not for me.- Books - there are some really cool options now - like 2 column reading, x-ray, so on.  The pages are not as "bright" white as the Gen1 - which at first I didn't like, but now realize it is actually easier to read on!  There is even a "shadow" where the crease of the book pages would be - it looks like a "real" book!- Auto-Brightness - is outstanding.  I no longer find myself adjusting for reading in bed vs. reading at office vs. using outdoors.  Used for first time yesterday outside (not in direct sunlight, of courst) - and found I had no problem seeing the document I was speaking from.  Outstanding...- Dual-channel - very nice, as I am now using the 5G side of my router, slowing the demand on the 2.4 side for all the other devices at home!- Colors, Resolution, Screen - absolutely beautiful!  What more to say!Folks - for this price - there is nothing out there that does what I WANT to do.  I looked at the fruit - too expensive, especially when you consider the apps I would need.  Nexus - didn't handle documents with the ease that Amazon/Send to Kindle/Fire does!  I have installed the free app from Amazon on all my desktops, which gives you the "Send to Kindle" option...sure makes it easy to get a document to my Bonfire!  Two clicks on the document, and zap - there it is on the carousel!  I do not "create" much on my Fire - that is what desktops and laptops are for...this is my "consumption" device...teaching, preaching, reading, studying, checking email, so on - which is what I would use any tablet for...and the larger format of this Fire is OUTSTANDING for this.  For the money saved vs. other tablets - I have purchased a 7" Fire for my daughter for Christmas...tell me another place you can get the large size and the mini size for these prices!!!Back to beginning - make sure you know what YOU WANT to do with a tablet - and let that drive your decision.  This Fire does ALL I want...and more!
Reviews.Title: Exactly what I needed

Reviews.Author: MamaBear
Reviews.Content: I received the 9" model today and absolutely love it. Here's a brief review of this product for the community to hopefully better assist people with making their purchase decision.A little background about my tablet experienceCurrently owned:Mobile device - AndroidTablet device - MS Surface windows RT, Kindle Fire HD 7"Ipad 3 - (wife's)This tablet size and weight surprisingly surpassed my expectation. The seer hardward looks and feels Quality. I love every detail amazon spent on engineering this: speakers and hd screen and obviously the price is unbelievably cheap.After having the Surface and Ipad experience, I felt like I should just sell those device and can have enough money to buy a Fire for everyone in my family. There is absolutely no reason why I shouldn't.
Reviews.Title: The best tablet for entertainment / consumption for the price

Reviews.Author: Rick
Reviews.Content: I have owned a few Android tablets and when I was looking to upgrade from my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 to a smaller / faster tablet, I was torn between the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 8.0 and the Kindle Fire HD 8.9. I finally went with the Fire based mainly on what appeared to be some impressive features for the price as well as the ability to utilize my Amazon Prime membership with the device (The Galaxy Tabs are not supported for some odd reason, yet the Ipads are?).Since there are thousands of reviews, I'm just going to give my TOP 5 pros and cons.The pros so far:1) Setup couldn't have been easier! I love how they had much of the tablet configured with my Prime movies and all my purchased music available, etc. Really well done!2) The tablet feels good in my hand and I love the "in between" size of 8.9" vs. the 10" I was used to and the 7" which I tried and was way too small for me.3) The screen is very nice and it has a surprisingly good resolution for watching movies. I will say it's great to finally have a tablet where I can utilize my prime membership.4) The app store has a good selection and downloading is even easier than the Google Play store. Also, it's nice to be able to make a subtle adjustment to the settings on the device so I can still download apps not available on the Amazon store. Amazon does need to beef up their selection of apps though.5) I think the speakers are pretty darn impressive! You can hear the difference between other tablets, it's that striking!The cons so far:1) I know others have said this ad nauseum, but paying extra for a charger that EVERY OTHER manufacturer includes just left a very bad taste in my mouth. I would have preferred they increased the price of the tablet by $10 or $15 bucks if they really couldn't afford to include it for the price they charge.2) Although I'm starting to get used to it (out of necessity), I'm not a fan of the carousel at all. I guess I understand why Amazon decided on a modified Android OS, but it would be nice if there was an option to revert back to the traditional Android look as it is far more user friendly than what Amazon has created. Frankly, it's making me question whether I made the right decision to purchase the Fire.2) Maybe it's just me, but the Amazon web browser is terrible! I don't know if I've seen pages load so slowly since I had an old 486 computer in the 90's! And I have a terrific internet connection at home with a blazing fast router, so I'm pretty sure it's not me. But the Amazon browser showed choppy displays, etc. On some pages, I couldn't even scroll down for 30 seconds to a minute until it loaded. Navigation wasn't good and it's not nearly as customizable as other browsers. Thank goodness I was able to add a third party browser which is working very well (fast and clear, etc.). I know I won't ever use the Amazon browser again unless they have a significant update which corrects all the performance issues.3) As has been stated by most, the power and volume buttons on the side are so flush to the device that they're extremely hard to access. Raising them just a hair would have made a big difference.4) The lack of a micro SD slot is a big miss and again makes me wonder if I made the right decision. I guess I was more than a little surprised at how much space Amazon's OS took up out of the 16GB. I would have gone for the 32GB but for some reason it was not eligible for the student discount, which didn't make much sense to me. On the plus side, I do like that all my Amazon media is stored on the cloud and easily accessible and I have a dropbox account for the rest, but there are times you want to store more on the actual device. And the way the Fire is setup, 16GB doesn't provide much flexibility at all.5) I was very surprised at how poorly downloaded magazines looked on this device. I have a PC World subscription and since they went all digital this past month, the only way for me to read the magazine is by downloading. I would have expected the Fire to be extremely adept at this, but it was quite the contrary. My old Galaxy Tab 2.0 had more clarity and smoother action from page to page. The Fire was extremely choppy and did not display the sharpest picture. In fact, when turning pages the images would distort for at least 5 to 10 seconds on the Fire where that never happened on my other tablets.In conclusion, I really WANT to like the Fire more than I do. Without an Android based option to view Amazon Prime content and all the options which should make this a "best in class" device, the execution of several key tablet essentials is inconsistent at best. Maybe there are explanations to the issues I've discovered that Amazon could answer but as of now, I'm not sure as to whether I'll keep this after the 30 day return option period.
Reviews.Title: Expected More...

Reviews.Author: Robin C. Bryant "Mrs. Bryant"
Reviews.Content: I LOVE the HD display as well as the size of the new kindle fire. The internet does move pretty fast WHEN it is connected. For some reason, a lot of the time, the WIFI will say its connects, but when I get on the internet or go to the bookstore, it says otherwise. I have to disconnect and reconnect the internet several times while I'm using it. Pretty annoying. I can't blame it on my internet provider because I still have 2 of the other kindle fires that STAY connected to internet for my kids. This is the only one I have this issue with. In addition, there have been several applications that I've tried to install, and it says that they already are. I've looked everywhere for them and cant find them.Despite these two seriously annoying issues, I STILL love it. Skype works well, and the bigger screen allows me to read better. I primarily use mine to read and occasionally surf the internet. The speakers, I think, work pretty well. Personally, I would never trade the kindle fire for an ipad. Then again, I've always been an android girl. Not really a fan of "i" products. Overall, I highly recommend this product despite its flaws. The positives highly outdo the negatives for me. :)
Reviews.Title: I like it!

Reviews.Author: Steven L Sanchez
Reviews.Content: This Kindle is my 4th Kindle and while the other 3 (Gen1  and 2 original Kindle Fire's) have been great this Kindle is a waste of time .... seriously..  the WiFi has way too many issues, I have had to reboot my router & modem many times which does not always fix the problem and I have had to reset the IP address assignment thinking it was that and still having too many connection problems.  The problem is the Kindle as my 3 desktops of Apple, Linux & Window PC all connect fine along with 2 window laptops and 3 ipads have never had any down time in regards to WIFI and this new Kindle Fire is just killing me connection wise... I have been up for most of the night trying to fix this issues and enough is enough.... I give up.. I will not do a factory Resest as I should not have to also due to the fact that I have some very very large gaming apps that take forever to download in the first place... I do not think I have ever complained about anything here on Amazon as this is a first for me.... this Kindle has turned into a waste of time and sleep.... I give up... Goodnight..
Reviews.Title: Too many wifi issues of not connecting (Waste of time)

Reviews.Author: M. Adams "M. Adams"
Reviews.Content: I purchased a Kindle Fire HD 8.9" tablet. There are things it does extremely well, but there were enough negatives about it that I ended up deciding to return it.The Good:- The screen is beautiful. It looks awesome on games, videos, books...everything, really. The size and orientation of the screen is also ideal for watching movies in a widescreen type format.- The speakers sound excellent. I had not imagined that I would ever enjoy watching a movie on a tablet versus on my TV, but the speakers on the Kindle Fire are very immersive and clear.- The size is comfortable. I had not wanted a full iPad because I've always thought my wife's is a bit bulky. Amazon has really nailed it in terms of a comfortable size and weight.- Integration with the Amazon store is excellent. For Prime videos, Kindle books, etc, the operating system is really well oriented to Amazon's content. The best software on the tablet is what is used for accessing Amazon content.The Bad:- All of my problems with the Kindle Fire are software oriented. The built in e-mail client synced for me the first time, then when I tried checking my e-mail again later, it just gave me the spinning icon and never refreshed. Not even after a reboot. The video camera worked, but when I tried getting Skype to work (which had been a selling point for me), the audio would work, but video would never turn on with Skype. It would try, then just give up. I tried to like the Silk browser, but I got tired of how every time you open it, it has to reload all tabs from scratch. It's time consuming, and also a bit buggy. The Facebook app on Kindle is just awful. If you were to look at a picture, you would have to hit the tab on the right, then find the back button just to get out of viewing the picture. I kept noticing that whenever I needed to check e-mail or Facebook, it was more convenient to put away the Kindle and to get out my iPhone than it was to deal with the Kindle apps.I think I was most disappointed to learn that the Kindle Fire cannot play digital copies of movies that I've purchased on Blu-Ray. I had bought extra storage in the Amazon Cloud, expecting to upload several of my movies to access whenever I desired to. But despite trying a variety of video player apps, I had to give up. Frankly, as you cannot play the common types of movie files that would necessitate larger cloud storage, despite a great job of integrating Kindle Fire with the Amazon Cloud, this renders the service much less useful than it would be otherwise.To summarize:Amazon has done an outstanding job on the Kindle Fire HD in terms of its hardware, its physical design, and its integration with Amazon. If what you are wanting is a device specifically for viewing Amazon video content, Kindle books, and playing games, this is an awesome purchase.I wanted a device for those reasons, but I also really wanted it for a bit of other productivity purposes, such as e-mail, internet, Facebook, etc. Unfortunately, as of the time of my review, the software for other basic uses is just too buggy. I was disappointed to see just how low of a priority it is for many developers to make apps for Android type devices. It wasn't that I couldn't get most of the types of apps I wanted; it was that the quality of apps developed is just so far lagging behind what I can get on my Apple devices.So in the end, I sincerely hope that in the upcoming months, Amazon will be successful in getting the bugs out of a lot of the software for the Kindle Fire HD. But for now, I just couldn't justify spending close to $500 for a device (after purchasing the 32GB 8.9" with extended warranty) that was so unreliable for e-mail, Facebook, Skype, and other apps. If you already have a tablet for productivity, and just need another tablet to keep you and your family from fighting over who gets to play a game or watch a movie, this makes a great second tablet.Incidentally, I did NOT go out and buy an iPad, and am planning to hold out for a few more months to see how things progress. Amazon has an amazing piece of hardware, but the software leaves a lot to be desired. I'll continue to root for them. If the software were as good as the hardware, this would be the best item on the market.
Reviews.Title: I liked it, but ended up returning it after a few days.

Reviews.Author: Keith Hamilton
Reviews.Content: I was concerned with my Kindle Fire HD 8.9 because the WiFi was loading all internet content slow. After retuning the first Kindle 8.9 then the replacement kindles 8.9 was acting the same as the initial, so I drove to the nearest Lowe's center to use their free WiFi.  Rightly, Kindle worked like a charm, so I knew it had something to do with my home network.  I have a smart-TV and Roku system, and the original Kindle Fire that worked well with my network so it came as a surprise that the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 was having slow connection problems.I fixed the problem by going online and changing a setting on my netgear wireless router. I had wpa-psk [tkip] + wpa2-psk [aes] as my wireless setting. By changing the setting to wpa2-psk [aes] I started to experience the WiFi speeds that I was accustomed to.So I must say now that Fire HD 8.9 is a wonderful tablet, and I highly recommend this product.
Reviews.Title: Hate then Loved

Reviews.Author: Scott Edison "se"
Reviews.Content: First of all, I will admit that I am biased. I'm a loyal Amazon customer and have been for years. I use Amazon Prime and the benefits that filter down to the Fire family of products pretty much makes the Fire HD a no-brainer.Other reviewers have provided thorough accounts of the good and bad aspects of the hardware, software etc.I'm going to keep this short and sweet.Who should buy the Kindle Fire HD 8.9?-Amazon enthusiasts. Do you already buy books, movies, music, spoken word audio, or have a Prime membership?-Value seekers. This is a very well spec'd device for the $. I don't think there is a better all around tablet in this range-Kindle owners that want to extend their experience to include music and video-Parents that are looking for a tablet that can be shared with kids. The on-board parental controls are good and it is pretty darn tough. You may want to consider the 7" for this purpose however.Who should not buy the Kindle Fire HD 8.9?-iOS fanatics. If you've already bought into that ecosystem and own music, movies, books and apps it clearly is not a great value-Bleeding edgers. If you are most interested in ultimate customization/flexibility this is not your tablet. It is easy to use, intuitive, and somewhat rigid in terms of configuration. If you want to customize, get a Nexus 10.I've owned two ipads and tried most of the competitive Android tablets and I think the Amazon Fire HD 8.9 is on par with the best if you set aside the fact that Apple's products feel more premium in your hand. The metal back, the higher res screen, and the Apple UI makes the iPad a little sexier. For me its not sexy enough to pay a premium on the device and for every piece of content going forward, but you can decide for yourself.
Reviews.Title: A very good option (for some)

Reviews.Author: Rogue, **Kindle Forum Pro** "Rogue, **Kindle ...
Reviews.Content: I've only had mine for 48 hours and so far i am thrilled with it. The screen quality is second to none. Everything looks fabulous on it. Text is crisp, pictures are sharp with great color and contrast and HD video is stunning. Dolby sound is the best I've heard on a tablet. Response time in regard to opening apps or starting a movie is very fast. Haven't found anything to dislike as of now other then the volume control buttons are flush with the bezel and not easy to feel. HDMI out to TV works seamlessly and picture and sound are superb. Well done Amazon!
Reviews.Title: Awesome device!

Reviews.Author: John Staradumsky
Reviews.Content: Has it really gotten to the point where we have to upgrade our electronic gadgets every year? It was just last fall, after all, that I bought my first Kindle Fire (that's when it was launched after all). I've been addicted to it ever since, and it goes wherever I do. Or at least it did.
