That's because Amazon announced a refreshed line of Kindle Fires for 2012, and I knew that I had to have one.Not so much because of the fact that there was anything wrong with my trusty Kindle Fire, mind you. It was just that the new ones packed some amazing features that I knew would enhance my Kindle experience with books, videos, music, audiobooks, games, and apps.New Kindle ModelsThe classic Kindle Fire would be dropped to $159, and is a great value at that price if you are looking for a solid, entry level device. It has even been slightly improved since 2011. The new Kindle Fire HD would boast even better screen resolution and a faster processor, more memory, and better Wi-Fi for $199. It was released shortly after being introduced in late September.I, however, was holding out for the larger, 8.9" Kindle Fire that was set to be released on November 20th. This was a trade-off to be sure, as my old Kindle, at 7 inches, was not much larger than a paperback book and immensely portable for that very reason. Still, I decided that I wanted the larger model at 8.9 inch screen size.The 8.9 inch kindle Fire HD comes in several flavors. I opted for the basic model that runs $299 and has 16 GB of internal storage. The next model up will run you $70 more at $369, with the only difference being 32 GB of onboard memory. Both of these kindles are Wi-Fi only.If you want a 4G LTE model, those are available starting at $499 for a 32 GB model and $599 for a 64 GB version. Monthly data plans are available, as well. For occasional use beyond the reach of a Wi-Fi network, you can pay $49 and get 250 MB of data a month for a year. This also includes an extra 20GB of free cloud storage and a $10 credit towards the Amazon app store.It should be noted that all of the Kindle Fire models will display ads when you start up the device. This is no big deal for me, but if you want to remove that feature it will cost you another $15.Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch vs. ipad MiniAs I said, I had opted for the $299 Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch model. But a funny thing happened on the way to the tablet. Apple, sensing that other makers were eating its lunch with smaller, cheaper tablets than the ipad, launched the ipad Mini before I received my new Kindle.That, I think, makes an excellent segue into an ipad Mini to Kindle Fire comparison. Obviously, at $299, the Kindle HD 8.9 inch will save you a few hundred over the ipad 3. But what about a comparison to the new ipad mini? I had a decision to make when the ipad mini was announced, especially since most of my family is already hooked on Apple and has been bugging me to convert. I had a considerable amount invested in Amazon content, though, which was a consideration. Most of it would be portable to an ipad, but the easy interface to your content that the Fire features would not be the same.For starters, the ipad Mini would cost me $30 more for a similar 16GB, Wi-Fi only model. Not so much as to make a difference, but then I started to look at the specs. First off was the display, and the Kindle clearly had the advantage over the ipad Mini. The 1920 by 1200 anti-glare display was clearly superior to the ipad's 1024 by 768 display, and of course the Kindle's screen is an inch larger. The Kindle HD also boasts a faster processor and Wi-Fi, and better speakers. The ipad mini seems to have the edge with it's camera.I decided to stick with my order for the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch model.The Kindle HD ArrivesEarlier I mentioned that my new kindle HD was to ship on November 20th. But as I was checking my Amazon account on the preceding Friday, I noticed that the $299 for the device had already been charged to my account. Sure enough, a quick hop over to Amazon.com indicated that the Kinddle HD had shipped the day before, and was on the UPS truck for delivery.Initial ImpressionsI was happy to get my kindle HD early, and popped it out of the box posthaste. I was immediately impressed by the larger display and new design. The device did not have the same heft as my own kindle in proportion to its size, and as a result felt less sturdy. Still, it's clear Amazon has learned from some of the mistakes they made with the original Kindle Fire.First off is the power button, which has been moved from the bottom to the top of the device. This was a major annoyance on my old Kindle Fire, as it had an alarming habit of being depressed when the tablet was held upright and trying to shut the power off.A volume control button is another welcome change; the first Kindle Fire did not have one at all. There's a new front facing camera and improved speakers on the sides of the device as well. The micro USB connection is joined by a micro HDMI output, too.One pet peeve that I have is that there is no power adapter included. While you do get a micro USB cable, this is really for connection purposes to a PC; same will not effectively charge your tablet. Actually, it's not really the omission of the power adapter that bugs me. Let's be fair, the kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch is a steal at $299, and you can get an Amazon "Powerfast" adapter for $19.99. It's just the plug really, and connects to the device via the included cable.My peeve, then, is that I would have liked to have known ahead of time that I needed to buy the power feed. Luckily, my old Kindle charger is compatible, but won't charge the device as quickly as the new one will. Annoyingly, Amazon changed the price to $9.99 on the adapter, but then when I went to buy one the price had changed again to $19.99 again with a $3 MP3 credit. I will hold off, I think, to see if it goes back down.My Kindle HD arrived fully charged and already configured to my Amazon account. I did need to download a software update which took about 30 minutes to fully configure and delayed my ability to start playing.Incompatible AppsWhile the power adapter omission was mildly irritating, the inability to use a number of the apps I had purchased for my Fire was downright infuriating, such to the point that I called Amazon and obtained an RMA. To be fair, most of my apps work on the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet. One in particular, though, that I use almost daily was incompatible when I received my tablet.The app in question is Comics by Comixology. I use this app almost daily, and have spent a considerable amount on digital comics that I and my sons read. To be unable to access these was intolerable, and I called Amazon Tech Support and e-mailed Comixology about the problem.I wasn't alone in my dismay; a number of new Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet owners also posted their displeasure on Amazon and the Comixology Facebook page. It seemed amazing to me that Amazon would not correct this, since they get a cut of every comic sold through the tablet app.Fortunately, Amazon and Comixology worked to resolve the incompatibility issues and I was able to download the app the following day. Of course, you may not find my tale of woe all that disheartening, especially if you don't read comics. You should, though, be concerned about the incompatibility of apps, and I should further advise that I do have a number still that won't work. This is  not a problem that Apple has had from ipad model to ipad model.NavigationAs with the original Fire, you will find navigation is fairly intuitive, and not much has changed in the department. The home screen is where the action is at, and you can always navigate to it from any book, video, or app by tapping the screen at the bottom to retrieve the menu; then hit the home icon. It's that easy. Once there, you will notice key information displayed at the top of the screen: "alerts" about software updates, new e-mail, and even a friend's latest move in "Words With friends"; the time; Wi Fi status; and battery strength.Gone, though, is the "Gear" icon that brught you to your settings menu in the past. Instead, you need to swipe down from the top center of the screen to get to some options: you can lock and unlock your device, adjust volume, screen brightness, see and choose wireless networks, sync with Amazon, see device information, and much more.You have several ways to access your content. The home screen is presented as a row of your most recently used books, apps, videos, and websites. This is called the "carousel", and you can scroll through it with the touch of a finger. Any time you access anything in the carousel, it gets bumped to the front of the line. Again, this is much the same as the first Kindle Fire.Holding your finger on a content pane in the carousel allows you to delete it from rotation, delete it from the device, or add it to your favorites. Favorites, however, are no longer displayed on a lower "shelf" on the home screen. Instead, there's now a favorites icon in the shape of a star beneath the carousel (it's also accessible from most other areas in the device). Tapping it at any time will bring up all the content in your favorites menu.You can also access content directly by category from a menu above the carousel.  In addition to the original Kindle Fire Options of Newsstand, Books, Music, Video, Docs, Apps, and Web, you can also choose from Shop, Games, Audiobooks, Photos, and Offers. From each of these categories, you can see content on the device and in the "cloud", and also access the Amazon store to purchase more. As with the first Fire, there is a search box on the home page and for each content category.How Much Storage Do I Need?The amount of storage that's right for you is entirely dependent upon the way you use your Kindle. At 16 GB of memory internally (only 12.8 GB of which is user accessible), I have roughly twice the storage that I had with my old Kindle Fire. Truth be told, I never used all of that, though I came close. Mostly that is because I generally access my content from the cloud. If you are not often in range of Wi-Fi and store more content locally, you may choose to opt for more storage.Managing your content and the amount of memory it consumes is simpler with the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet. From the settings menu, simply choose "Device" and "Storage" and you'll get a detailed analysis of your usage by content type. Tapping any of these categories will bring you to a list of that content; you can delete what you no longer want locally to increase available memory.The CloudThe Cloud allows you to store content on Amazon's servers for access through a Wi-Fi or cellular connection with compatible models of the Fire HD. The Fire HD has excellent Wi Fi detection and transfer speed capabilities, indeed even better than the ipad 3 offers thanks to the dual Wi-Fi antennas. This allows you to transfer files to your device in no time.Amazon gives anyone with an Amazon account 5 GB of storage space for free. You can use it to store documents, videos, and music for your Fire. Any music, magazines, books, and videos you purchase through Amazon do not count towards your limit. Need more space for your stuff? Amazon offers the option to buy more, the cheapest plan being $20 for an upgrade to 20 GB. Best of all, this option includes unlimited music storage. Amazon recently copied Apple's "matching" option; if they have the same music in their library that you are uploading they will automatically upgrade your tracks to 256K or better quality. There is no charge for this with one of the paid cloud plans.Available ContentAmazon has the drop on anybody else in the content category. Not even Apple comes close, except perhaps in music, but Amazon offers reduced price songs and albums that I have rarely seen on itunes. In addition, many purchases on Amazon come with promotional MP3 credits, so you can download songs as a bonus. While it's true that you can access this content through other devices, for me the integrated interface with the Kindle Fire makes them much easier to get to.While it is true that the content is not unique to this device and may seem a curious component of a review of the Kindle Fire HD, I truly believe that it is a very important factor in your decision on whether or not to buy this device or an ipad, Surface, or Nexus tablet.NewsstandAmazon offers a number of magazines and newspapers by single issue or by subscription. You can find such favorites as Time, The Economist, Forbes, Us, Popular Science, and much more.BooksAmazon has a massive library of books to choose from, most of the latest titles and lots of classics, too. Many books are free. I had a large library already from Amazon, so I was good to go with my new Fire HD. I generally keep a few on my device and store the rest in the cloud for later retrieval. As with all e-readers, I love the convenience of being able to download a book the day it is released. No trip to the store required.Also par for the course is the ability to adjust display (meaning font and print size) to your liking, though sadly the text-to-speech option that was present on the very first Kindle is still not available. Here's hoping Amazon brings it back someday.MusicThe Fire is a surprisingly good music player. Although it will never replace my Zune as my preferred music device, I do enjoy streaming music from the cloud while web surfing or playing games. As with the Kindle Fire, the Fire HD boasts an impressive little music player that streams high-quality audio to your headphones from the cloud or local storage.There are a number of apps available for music lovers as well, most of them free. Pandora, Spotify, and Iheart Radio are all available for the Fire HD.VideoStill annoying is the inability to play digital copy from my blu ray purchases. That said, there are plenty of options for video with the Fire. The Amazon video store offers a large library to select from, with much content available for rental or purchase. Any purchased content can be accessed from the cloud or the device.When renting a title, Amazon offers the convenient option of downloading to the device so that it can be accessed when Wi Fi is not available. You have 30 days to start watching; once you do the content will be deleted after a 48-hour window.DocumentsDocuments can be accessed from the cloud or the device for access as well. Quickoffice is included at no charge with your Fire HD. This comes in handy, though the files are locked for read access (though different apps allow you to alter them).You can upgrade to the full version of Quickoffice for just $15. I in fact did this shortly after purchasing my first Kindle Fire. This allows easy editing and creation of documents.AppsAmazon is not even close to offering the app content that Apple does, and likely never will. While the library of Android apps available for the Kindle has grown, it is still only a subset of those available on most dedicated Android devices (such as my cell phone). Bottom line for me, though, is that the apps catalog on Amazon suits my needs, and while I may not always be able to get an app I want, I can usually find the app I need.AudiobooksA large library of audiobooks is available through Audible.com, an Amazon company. These are my constant companions on the way to and from work, and help me to endure the traffic.WebThe Fire HD uses the Amazon Silk browser. It's intuitive, learns from the sites you visit most frequently, and starts loading them in advance on its servers when you start surfing (you can shut this off if you prefer). You can bookmark favorites, and websites look good when displayed in either mobile or normal formats. Overall, though, it's not all that different than most of the popular browsers out there.PerformanceAs with the Kindle Fire, Performance of the Kindle Fire HD has pleased me overall. Using the performance of my old Kindle Fire as a baseline, it's easy to see the improved performance on this model.Wi-FiWeb pages load more quickly than in the past with the improved Wi-Fi connectivity. Video and music stream flawlessly with a strong source as well. All the better to access your content from the cloud.Video DisplayThe display is perhaps the most impressive new aspect of the Kindle Fire HD. Video is crisp and clear, and HD movies look better than ever. Apps and games are most impressive, with some HD Apps like "Angry Birds Star Wars" appearing in glorious, sharp detail and amazingly rich, vibrant colors. Digital comics from the Comixology app truly dazzle.Books, also, are easier to read, at least for me. One of the disadvantages of the Fire line is that it lacks the e-ink of the original Kindle. That device was much like reading a conventional book with e-ink. The Fire's display was prone to impart eye fatigue for this reviewer much more quickly. Happily, with the higher resolution and improved display, this does not seem so much a problem with the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet.On Screen KeyboardCertainly, the larger display of the Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet allows facilitates the use of the keyboard for e-mail and word processing much more easily. Quite simply, it's much easier to type on the screen keys with the larger display. Often, I found myself making numerous typos on my old Kindle Fire because the keys were just too small; tilting is sideways to increase size reduced my content space. Not as much of an issue with the larger Fire HD.ProcessorSo far, I haven't noticed any benefit from the faster processor. All my games and apps run pretty much as smoothly as they did on the original Kindle Fire. Perhaps that's a compliment to that device.SpeakersAnother of the features that Amazon touts as much improved are the speakers. "Exclusive Dolby audio and dual stereo speakers for crisp, booming sound without distortion"  are promised. From my standpoint? Not so much. While it's true they are slightly louder, a welcome improvement, and have a marked increase in stereo separation, they have little bass at all. I'm not really disappointed about this in such a small chassis to be fair, just don't expect to replace your boom box with the Kindle Fire HD for audio playback.Battery Life and ChargingBattery life has averaged about ten hours of assorted use (apps, books, music, videos) from a full charge. Your mileage may vary with your usage mix; apps and games devour power the most quickly. The device does take a long time to charge with my old Kindle Fire adapter (similar AC adapters can also be used).An hour's charge brought me from 5% to 40% charged; it took another two hours to fully charge my tablet.A Few New FeaturesBluetoothWorth mentioning is Bluetooth capability, not present on the original Kindle Fire. So far, I have been unable use it to play audiobooks and music through my car's speakers, though I was able to successfully pair my new Kindle to the car.CameraA front-facing HD camera is another new feature on the Kindle HD. While there is no native app for it, it does work with Skype for video calls. You can also use it with facebook to record photos and videos; there are several apps for the camera available for purchase. Picture quality and sound recording are very good, indeed, though I find that the front-facing aspect makes it difficult to take photos of things other than yourself.Amazon PrimeIn addition to the second-day shipping upgrades Amazon prime offers, you can also access a large library of movies and TV shows with your Kindle Fire HD as a member. In addition, there is a large library of books that are not otherwise free available for borrowing, one per month. Prime is, it should be noted, an additional $79 a year, and you are under no obligation to purchase it.Overall ImpressionsAlthough I still have major concerns about the incompatibility of apps, I am nonetheless very happy with my new Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet. Concerns remain that content I purchase now may not be available for future models. Amazon uses the perpetual access of your purchased content from the cloud as a selling point, so I would expect to be able to use it in the future.Still, the Kindle Fire HD shines in so many other areas that I can overlook this. The brilliant display, increased size, faster Wi-Fi, camera, Bluetooth, slightly better sound, all make this a truly useful one-stop entertainment device. The $299 price seals the deal.The Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch device truly completes the evolution of the Kindle from dedicated e-reader to multi-purpose tablet.
Reviews.Title: Excellent Buy Dispute a Few Problems

Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I'm not going to write a book here.  Many others have talked the stats and features.  I am very happy with this device.  I had the original Fire and my new 8.9 blows it away.  Amazon has fixed most everything that I had issues with on my original Fire.  Everything is great!Update#1:  11/17/12  After playing with this all morning, I'm tempted to raise it a star.  I will say that the browser has crashed a few times, which is a problem that I had with my old Kindle Fire.Update#2:  11/30/12  I'm still enjoying the Kindle.  I've yet to try out the bluetooth.  I've been looking for a good bluetooth headset.  I'm still waiting on my case, I hope to have it today.  I'm really hoping the case helps with holding the tablet while reading.  That is about the one thing that I prefer the 7" for was it was easier to hold for long reading sessions.
Reviews.Title: Very Nice

Reviews.Author: S. Sutton
Reviews.Content: This kindle does not compare to the quality of the first kindle I purchased.  The silk browser is the main problem and locks up constantly and has performed that way since day one.  Can't even shop on Amazon with it without it locking up several times per session.
Reviews.Title: very disappointing

Reviews.Author: Stephensa
Reviews.Content: So, I've owned the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" for just over a month. Just long enough to not be able to return it and buy the  32 gig 4G version at near the  same price I paid for my 32 gig non-4G version. It really sticks in my craw as it were, but that's the way the technology ball crumbles. Its irritating but no reflection on the device. As for the device, I Love It! I use it every day, often and with much glee and happiness.  I own an original Kindle e-reader, a first generation Kindle Fire, and now the HD. My wife has an IPAD and when I got the first gen  Kindle Fire, I liked it. I really did. However I still looked longingly and with much envy at her Ipad.  For good reason.  No longer my friends, no longer.  My new  8.9" Fire HD is wonderful. It has plenty of storage for video, books and apps when I am out of Wi Fi range and when using wi-fi it is very quick on loading web pages, downloads of various media, and I can watch Hulu, Netflix, etc with impunity. Also, I have downloaded some very graphic/ram intensive games and the action is smooth and the video amazing. It really is a fantastic experience. I also like the feature wherein I can plug the unit into my television (HDMI) and watch movies or play games on a big screen. Is it an Ipad? No. In some ways it is better, in some ways not so much.  Is it a laptop?  No.  But that is not what it is meant to be. It is a great media device at a fantastic price.  It is not a portable work computer. You will not crunch numbers or create elaborate spreadsheets though they do have some office type apps available. Its a media device and I believe it does that job very well at a great price point. Do your research, know what you are buying and if it meets your needs go for it.  I give it both  thumbs up.
Reviews.Title: I like it, I really like it!

Reviews.Author: Richard Mantz
Reviews.Content: Hello all,I thought I would give a brief review of the Kindle HD after using for a couple of weeks now including a trip to Korea.I have used Kindle products for a couple of years now, so it made sense to try the Fire, IF it would meet my expectations. I have a Kindle touch that has been my constant companion for since they were released. I had and earlier kindle reader, and my wife has the original Kindle Fire.I can say that overall, I have been very impressed! Since I travel extensively for work, most out of the country, i was concerned that the HD would be basically a brick outside the USA. Not so. I was able to use FEAT VPN app, then a VPN service. I was able to stream video with no issues.Picture quality was outstanding! IF streaming speed slowed down, I would see some pixelation, but this is streaming speed not the device. Hd movie I downloaded to the device had extremely good detail. WAY better than my laptop!Sound quality was surprisingly good. No, you are not going to get big booming bass on movies and music. But the sound quality was better than any tablet I have had a chance to play with, including the almighty iPad. In fact, the sound had nearly a surround sound quality. I found that in my hotel I preferred to listen through the device speakers and not my headphones. The surround effect was that good!Apps. People make a big deal about this. I borrowed a friends ipad, and yes there are more apps. More worthless apps! Seriously, just because there are a gazzilion apps doesn't make anything better. Are there apps that do what you need? That is what you need to find out. For me, I have found everything I need without an issue, and quite a few more i don't need! I'm not a big game player, so maybe that's why I haven't had an issue.Navigation. I actually find the navigation pretty intuitive, but then again, I have an Android phone. I find it easier to use than the phone, and easier than my wife's original fire. Maybe it's just the bigger screen size. Also, I did not not notice the "lag" that many people mention, except once. Something must have been going wrong because the response was getting slower, then, the Kindle re-booted itself. after that, it was back to normal. I'll keep an I on this to see if it happens again.Browsing. Pretty good. From a user standpoint, I don't see where Silk is either faster or slower for most browsing activities. The recent tabs gets a bit full, but that's easy to clear. Overall, I pretty pleased, but I do miss flash on occasion. I found that the Kindle stayed connected much better than my laptop, and picked up a lot more wifi networks as well. On my n-network at home, it is killer fast! The only issue i had was at the Inchon airport Asiana lounge. I could not get the kindle to connect to their wifi service. My phone had trouble as well, but not my laptop. I noticed other people with different devices not having issues, so there was some sort of compatibility issue.Reading. Ok. I much prefer reading on my kindle touch. It's just much easier on the eyes, and superior in daylight. This is true on with comparing to anything that's not e-ink. Not to mention that the battery on my touch will last for a month with wireless off. The touch will NOT be leaving by bag of toys no matter what other device i have.Music--pretty much a player. Good sound from speakers but way better with headphones.Overall, I am very pleased. I found i used my Kindle far more than my laptop on this trip, including checking and responding to emails with the built in exchange client. I only have the 16gb version, so I might upgrade to the 32gb so I can put more movies on to watch while on the plane.
Reviews.Title: Kindle HD 8.9

Reviews.Author: Mary A. Prudner
Reviews.Content: I love my Kindle Fire HD 8.9"!  I am still learning what I can do on it but so far it is great fun!The picture quality is outstanding!
Reviews.Title: Love it!

Reviews.Author: Todd in SC
Reviews.Content: I got the original Kindle Fire last year, but couldn't decide if I wanted to upgrade or not, since I've thoroughly enjoyed it.  But, the bigger screen was the main selling point, given these aging eyes, as well as the specs.I ordered it on Sunday night, Dec 9th, around 10pm EST, and it was on my doorstep less than 48 hours later.  I opened the box, and it exceeded my expectations in size.  It's heavier than the original Fire, but thinner.  I booted it up, and to my surprise, all the books I had purchased over the past year were already downloaded on it (a fact that I had overlooked when ordering).  You do have to tap on them to download, but it takes maybe 2 seconds.  There are more options for the font size, and moving from page to page is just as smooth as the original.The screen is beautiful, and crystal clear.  Scrolling through the books and apps is very easy.  I'm not big on the games, except for Angry Birds, and it plays just fine.  I'm more into the news apps, as well as Facebook and Twitter, and the HD screen makes the pictures and text crisp and clear.  The speakers sound better than on the original, however as other people have said, their position on the back sometimes makes it hard to hear, especially if you're holding it to where they're covered.  But, connect it to a set of speakers or earphones, and there's no problem. I haven't tried the Bluetooth option yet, but do have Bluetooth enabled speakers.I would highly recommend this.  I had thought about joining the iPad craze, but for the price, this device was the best option for me, given what I use it for.  I just couldn't see spending that much more money, when Amazon makes a quality product like this that performs just as well, in my opinion.
Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9"

Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I just first want to say that I was a little bit skeptical about our Kindle Fire HD 8.9".  I have an ipod and was used to how the apps and the layout were.  So when I began using the Kindle all I did was kept comparing it to Apple.  Well this is NOT an Apple product.  This is such an amazing device by an amazing company.  One of our main reasons for buying the Kindle was b/c we love to watch movies.  We are able to watch all of our movies that we have bought from Amazon right on the Kindle.  The picture is so clear and the sound quality is wonderful even with headphones on.  We were able to download all of our movies and still have plenty of room.  The other thing that has really impressed me is the Kindle FreeTime app for kids.  I have a 4 year old son who knows how to navigate the Kindle already.  We set up his profile on the FreeTime app and now I do not have to worry about him clicking on something he should not.  Now we have the Kindle locked down pretty good so that so get to anything you have to put in your pin, but with this App I do not have to worry at all.  We have put his games, movies and books in this spot and let him at it.  He will ask us in the morning can he play his Kindle.  I will say I wish you were able to download apps from the Google sight instead of thru Amazon but one thing I have noticed is they are always adding apps so I know the ones I would like will be there sometime in the future.  The screen is big enough so that if I need to enter in information on a website my fingers are not fumbling around.  We have even gotten rid of Netflix and began using the Amazon Prime feature.  We love it.  There are so many movies to choose from that are free.  I highly recommend this tablet especially to people with children.
Reviews.Title: Great Product

Reviews.Author: fredsfan
Reviews.Content: I received this on Saturday, immediately took it out of the box to play with it - no charging required.  I turned it on, followed the steps on the screen and was ready to go.  The Kindle is pre-registered so there is nothing really to do except set up the wi-fi and the Kindle walks you through the steps. I purchased the AT&T; package and it too was extremely simple.  I honestly don't understand people complaining about how they can't figure this out. If you do have trouble, there is a help section that is clearly marked.LOVE how the "back" button is on the of the screen, IMHO, much smarter. The swiping on this kindle is far superior than on my Samsung Galaxy S II phone, few, if any wrong words. Keyboard is easy to use, numbers/letters/characters where you expect them.  Internet speed is great, able to play videos on youtube for my son.  Volume sounds great. I very easily found the settings features and played around with all the options. Obviously there will be a little exploring time to find where stuff is located, this is expected and part of the fun.This is really a very easy to use tablet. I don't want to say it is only for "beginners" because it has a lot of great features if you want to delve into it, but it is easy to use and doesn't take a lot of figuring out. If you have a smart phone, this is easier to use.  If you are familiar with a touch screen, it is a snap.  If you know how to surf the internet, you are golden.  If you are not familiar with the above, it is not the tablet it is the learning curve - don't rate the tablet low because you don't know how to use it. If you WANT to learn how to use it, it is very simple. Some of the negatives are coming from people who expect to know how to use something they have never used before and aren't interested in learning.It come with a USB charging cord, not an issue to me as this standard. It doesn't have a huge users manual but again, standard and there is a help section on the kindle that walks you through things in exact detail.I love this, it does what I expect it to do. Picture is amazing, touch screen responive, sound is great.
Reviews.Title: Short, sweet, dumb-dumb review

Reviews.Author: Victor A. Buttaro
Reviews.Content: Upgraded from the Fire first edition to the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 (with special offers) and I got to  say it's well worth the upgrade. The larger size and the the sleeker case design help it fit into one's hands a lot better than the first edition. The 8.9 inch screen with a resolution of 1920x1200 makes for beautiful viewing experience. It's my home PC resolution squeezed into a display 1/3 the size. The Dual-band, dual-antenna Wi-Fi (MIMO) is also a welcome addition. Finally I can use the 5 GHz frequency on my router. (As a side note; if you're looking to upgrade make sure you get one that can transmit in both frequencies at the same time)The new UI runs a lot smoother than the last edition and looks nicer. The black background just works much better. Please note the UI runs though runs on top of a newer version of Android than the last revision so some thing have changed slightly. But it's nothing that one won't pick up in 15 minutes or less. Haven't had a chance to test out many games that would actually stress the tablet out yet. My favorite pinball game does run smoother and just look beautiful under the new higher resolution.She isn't just a pretty face; my baby also knows how to sing! While I haven't tested it out with any movies yet; the new Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is also much improved in the sound department over the first version.It's not all perfect though. My only real issue is with the removable of the power/charge light. Not really sure why this was removed as it was helpful. having said that though there is (as other have probably mentioned) a program called Battery HD that you can download/buy. I purchased the Pro version and one of the things it allows is to set alerts for battery level. It's the perfect way for your Fire to tell you when it's all charged up or when it gets to a level you wished to be warned about. Still wish that the light hadn't been removed though. Hopefully Amazon will add a software method that will make it easier to see/hear charge status.And yes, unfortunately it doesn't come with a charger. I would think in this day and age people already have chargers but that seems to be a major complaint. My suggestion is get Amazon's high powered charger if you don't have one. You're going to need one for other devices in your life anyway and a high powered one is the way to go. This one will charge your Kindle and probably every other device without a charger you'll get in the future.So finally, should you upgrade from the first edition Kindle Fire? YES without a doubt. You already know what you're getting into with Amazon's device and the market place, so that won't be an issue. And you'll be getting something that is much improved. As for new users, as long as you know what you'll be getting in advance I say go for it! The Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is a great piece of hardware for the price.
Reviews.Title: My Kindle Fire grew up and learned some new tricks

Reviews.Author: Charles W. Weigand "Crossfire Chuck"
Reviews.Content: Crystal clear is an understatement.  We pre-ordered and received the unit before any retail stores in the area.  As an avid I Pad user, this is the absolute closest thing at a price you can actually afford without taking out a loan.  I purchased it for my wife due tot he size and abilities.  Yikes, did I get a special treat (That alone made the purchase outstanding).  I call it the "fun pad" because that is exactly what it is, FUN.  Let us not diminish the work abilities and multi tasking.  The size is more comfortable without making it bulky and difficult to hold (for those midnight oil reading sessions).  Set up was a couple of minutes.  What a knock out picture.  For those who cannot swing the I Pad; this would be the way to go.  Maybe some accessories will result in another  "special treat".  The possibilities are endless.  With all the tablets out there, it is difficult to chose.  I purchased some early Kindles for relatives who are "hooked" on reading their books, magazines anywhere, anytime.  With declining eye sight, options can help.  I will admit I have not been able to "play" with the HD, my wife says you can have it when you pry it from my cold dead hands.  I guess that says it all!
Reviews.Title: Holy Cow, what a unit.

Reviews.Author: Val4
Reviews.Content: I am new to tablets. Im no computer expert, so I guess this review is for the everyday person like me that knows enough about computers to use them effectively but doesnt really get into all of the technicalities. I got my kindlefire hd 8.9 about a week ago and I havent been able to put it down. A few months ago I ordered the Ipad but I returned it right away after having buyers remorse about the price tag of almost $1000.  Im so happy that I decided to go with the kindle. I think it is definitely worth the price. A lot of people have complained about the ads but I only see an ad when I turn on the kindle or when I wake it up, other than that, I havent seen any ads. If you're a bargain shopper like me, you wont mind the ads one bit for the lower price.I love that it seems that attention was given to the details like a rubber back, light weight, the size is perfect to fit in my purse, and the ability to hold it in any position and type. Ive read a lot of reviews about how great the speakers are but since this is my first tablet I really dont have anything to compare them to but I can say that they are clear at the maximum volume.Im thinking about getting one for my 22 year old daughter. Her first question was does it have instagram. Unless I need to do more searching, no there is no instagram app which is disappointing.  I even went directly to the instagram site and my pics wouldnt load.  Im also disappointed with the facebook app that does not allow me to scroll down my wall as far as I want. I can only go partly down the page then it stops scrolling. Another problem that Ive had is that the internet browser keeps crashing, very irritating. Ive gone to websites that require flash to open content but the kindle says that its not supported, again irritating.  I dont know if this is the norm for certain content not to be able to open on tablets but if it is then this is a major drawback of tablets for me.  The point of having a tablet is so that I dont have to pull my laptop out just to browse the web. I also have to add that the volume and power buttons are hard to find since they are sort of hidden around the edge. It would be helpful if these buttons stood out more maybe by being a different color or even making the power button a switch that slides up and down vs a push button which is what it is now. Finally amazon NEEDS to include the charger. It was very inconvenient to get the kindle then realize that I could only charge it on a pc so I had to go back, buy the charger, and wait for UPS to deliver it.So far the kindle fire hd 8.9 has been fun to play around with and learn but if the concerns that I expressed were fixed, it would be perfect.UPDATE for new users like me:Check out The Android Guy on youtube. He has great tips on downloading other apps and browsers that arent usually available on the kindle. I was even able to get Instagram! I love him!
Reviews.Title: Kindle fire Hd 8.9 New User

Reviews.Author: kylee1
Reviews.Content: I owned an ipad2, the original kindle fire, and a kindle e-reader. I used the ipad mostly for watching movies and playing games because of the larger screen, but prefered Amazon movie streaming to itunes because I have an Amazon Prime account, so I can get tons of movies and tv shows for free. I used the kindle fire to read in bed so I didn't have to use a separate light source and found the ipad to be too big and heavy for reading. I then had to get the kindle e-reader for reading outside. I wanted something that would do the job of all three and I found it in the Kindle Fire HD 8.9inch. I thought I would need a kindle paperwhite for reading in bed , but have found the Fire to be the perfect size and I like the option of using a black background with white type because it doesn't let off a lot of light and doesn't cause eye strain. I have sold my ipad and don't miss it at all! I never used the camera on the ipad except for skyping or facetime so I don't see what the big deal is about the Fire only having a front facing camera because I don't know why you would want to use it for a camera anyway.
Reviews.Title: Not disappointed

Reviews.Author: Rebecca McLane
Reviews.Content: I got mine yesterday, and have already been able to do so many things with it without having to do much searching for help.  I already have a Toshiba Thrive tablet, which I really really like, but it certainly does not have anything close to the high resolution of this tablet.  Unlike a lot of reviews for the smaller version, which came out several weeks ago, I found that it is very intuitive and easy to set up and use.  I have been watching the app store, and more and more apps are becoming available for the HD.  Most of the apps which I had purchased previously for my Thrive can be used on this tablet, and I found some wonderful RPG's which are not available for my Thrive (Final Fantasy III, for one example).  I am just beginning to explore all the things I can do, and I will be looking at a way to organize my books (Amazon - you REALLY need to develop a collection app for the Fire and Fire HD!!!), since I have over 1600 of them.  I strongly recommend the Battery HD Pro app, since you can set it to give you an audible alert both when your battery is low (can choose what level it gives the alert) and when the battery charging is complete.  All in all, so fare I love it and feel that it was a great deal for the price!
Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is great!

Reviews.Author: Kindle Customer "BBB"
Reviews.Content: Plus Amazon has THE BEST customer service out there...and that can be equally as important as the quality of the device. We wont repeat whats been said other than if you're looking for the BEST picture & sound quality for movies...Netflix....Huluplus...HBOGO etc. reading...web surfing and more...this is far better than Samsungs 10.1 note and even our ipad!!! If/when Amazon ever decides to do a 10.1 or larger tablet...they'll blow EVERYONE including Apple, out of the water! This is an Exceptional product.... you won't regret purchasing!!
Reviews.Title: sending Samsung note 10.1 back..will never give up my Kindle Fire 8.9 HD- THE BEST TABLET OUT THERE

Reviews.Author: camping queen
Reviews.Content: After hours of research I decided that this was the device for me.Than the long and some what impatient wait for this to arrive, I have to say that I am very happy.I do not seem to have a problem with the power button, once I found it, which did take a minute, I havenot had a problem since than.Set up was very easy and the device walks you right through it.Books look great on this device.  I do have to turn down the brightness to read, my eyes are somewhat light sensitive, other that that they are very crisp and clean looking.  I could see not havinga way to organize your books in the future being a pain, but at this time I don't have that many booksin my library.There are more than enough apps for me.  Haven't run across one that I am missing at thistime.My email is not compatible with this device, but I really don't care.  I prefer to go to my emailthrough the web anyway, which I am able to do with no issues using silk.I have watched tv shows available through my amazon prime account and they have been veryclear and the sound has been great. Netflix was a little glitchey at first, but than it cleared itself up,I only used it for a few minutes to test out the app, so I am not sure how it would work for a longperiod of time.I have surfed the web with silk almost everyday.  I have not run into any issues.The keyboard does not give me any problems, if you are used to using an iphone or smartphonekeyboard you should be fine.  If not, it will take a little time to get used to.Just to give people an idea about this kindle,  I do not feel that it will ever replace my laptop, nor doI want it to. I have a macbook that I paid a lot of money for so why would I want it to.I have an iphone as well, which I enjoy using and am comfortable with, therefore if there are apps Iwant from apple I can get them on my iphone.  I also use my iphone for music so I at this time I don't see theneed to have my music on my kindle, that may change or it may not.I bought the prowerfast charger, it does what it is supposed to do, no issues there either.Over all if you are looking for an ereader that has a few more bells and whistles, this is a great choice.If you are looking for a machine to do everything a computer does, this is not it.  I would recommend youlook into some of the newer computers coming out.
Reviews.Title: Love it, Love it, Love it!!!!!

Reviews.Author: prisrob "pris,"
Reviews.Content: I have the first generation kindle, a Kindle Fire and now the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 16 GB. I pre-ordered this Kindle the day it was announced in September. I was pleased to receive my new Kindle at least two weeks earlier than advertised.The Kindle arrived in the same black packaging as the Kindle Fire. Easy to open with the side zip. Once out of it's box, the Kindle is sleek, thinner than the i-Pad. It is the same height. Simple directions are found in a side pocket of the inner packaging.The buttons are placed along the upper right side, horizontally. They are flush to the tablet, and for some these buttons seem to be more difficult to find.  Turn the Fire on, swipe the lock key, the tablet asks for your Wi-Fi password, you select your time zone and confirm your account. Very easy compared to many other tablets. Now, the real experience begins. Your apps have been automatically configured from other kindles. There is an amazing array of other apps to choose from. The Kindle brings you through the entire process. You click on next to go from one page to the next in the setup process.One of the best improvements, among many is email. Very easy to set up, the email is crisp and clear.  The Fire HD 8.9 is the version to get. Its larger, higher-resolution screen better facilitates Amazon's still-new Kindle Fire interface, and its faster processor makes for a much smoother and zippier experience.. The tablet's availability in a Wi-Fi-only version ($299 for 16GB, $369 for 32GB) and a 4G LTE Wireless version $499 for 32GB, $599 for 64GB, is superb. Speakers are mounted on either side and the sound is so much better.Streaming films from Netflix or Amazon Prime is the way to go. Crisp, clear vision and the HD sound!  Moving from one app to another is very fast. I purchased 'Best 100 Kindle Fire HD Apps' as suggested by another reviewer, and it is an excellent source. For $.99, a great deal of information is available.So far, I have been disappointed with the selection of Kindle Fire HD covers, expensive. I will do more research to find one that is perfect for me.I am extremely pleased with this Kindle Fire HD 8.9 tablet. It has everything I have wanted in a tablet with faster service and Amazon's experience. The lack of a specific charger is not a problem, I have several I can use. I have been listening to Mumford and Sons while writing this review, and the sound is just superb!Highly Recommended. prisrob 11-20-12Amazon Kindle PowerFast for Accelerated Charging (not included with device, for use with the new Kindle Fire or Kindle Fire HD models)
Reviews.Title: Sleek, Thinner, Tablet

Reviews.Author: Mbail
Reviews.Content: Very impressed with my new Kindle Fire HD 8.9.  I have the original Kindle Fire and have been happy with it, but the new version addresses most of my gripes with the previous version.  First and foremost, storage; I purchased the 32 Gb version and it was well worth the extra money.  I have download a couple audio books, a music playlist with about 50 songs, all of my magazines, a few books and most of my apps and have about 23 Gb left.  Doesn't sound like a lot, but I was constantly managing the space on my original Kindle Fire and would have never downloaded music or audiobooks, it just took too much space.  The gmail integration is much improved.  I can move e-mails to my gmail folders with the native app and it also syncs to my contacts and gmail calendar.  Ahh, so much nicer.  There is more customization available such as the ability to set the brightness to auto, turn off the last web page showing on the carousel, turn on notifications for applications, and turn off Amazon Home recommendations.  Amazon has learned there lesson well.  Give us an interface that is easy to use, but give us some customization to make it pretty.  The HD screen is very nice.  I plugged the device into my flat screen and the picture and sound were good.  Bluetooth was easy to use and worked with my bluetooth headphones, including forwarding through songs.In fact, I would have rated this five stars if not for the Silk browser.  Don't get me wrong, it gets the job done, but it crashes on the more intesive websites (esp. Adobe).  Also, if Amazon is driving us to the cloud, why can I not store my bookmarks there?  I have every confidence Amazon will get it right with Silk, but I can't give it five stars since one of the main reason I have a tablet is a bit buggy.
Reviews.Title: Vast Improvement

Reviews.Author: Donald Atkinson
Reviews.Content: I love Amazon, and I love my e-Ink Kindles so I had high hopes for the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" and honestly I didn't think it was that bad for the first couple of weeks.  I've had it for about 2 months now and the only way to describe my feeling toward it at this point is buyer's remorse.  I had bought this as a replacement for my original iPad which is no longer supported and it has gotten quite sluggish at pretty much everything.  Initial impressions were good--but it is no iPad--it was also half the cost.  There were annoyances like it just freezing up completely for 30 seconds at a time before resuming what it was doing like nothing happened, but I figured I could live with it for at least a year despite those and it wouldn't have cost me any more than my iPad cost me since I got less than three years worth of useful life out of it.  BUT, two months in I am now getting about 10 minutes worth of use out of a complete charge!  Let me say that again in case you weren't paying attention...10 MINUTES USE FROM A COMPLETE CHARGE!!!  With a full charge I play about 10-20 minutes of Simpsons Tapped out on it (which doesn't take the battery meter down very much) and then leave it until the next day when I get home from work and it ALWAYS says that the battery is dead.  I don't have any notifications turned on so I don't know what it is doing all day that drains the battery--but at this point it is nothing more than a $400 paperweight--yes, I bought the ridiculously expensive cover too.I will unequivocally state that I'd pay twice as much for an iPad.EDIT:So after letting this sit for a day I realized that it wasn't much more than venting and didn't really provide much useful information.  So, here is something a little more useful to add.The display is excellent, though the touch sensor is not the greatest--does not seem to be very accurate or sensitive and suffers from the general lag of the system.  The system is a bit slow to respond to input, but seems to run most things pretty quickly.  I'm not sure what might cause this other than the overhead of Android.Many complain about the lack of the Google Play store, but I don't really see this as that big an issue.  You can side load anything that you download from Google Play on another Android device--it is just not nearly as convenient.The placement of the power button is annoying--I'm constantly accidentally turning it on or turning it off.  (Or at least I did when I was using it more.)Web browsing is one of the major things I had planned on using it for.  Web browsing is not a joy.  I don't remember specifics but after about a week I gave up on it for that purpose and went back to my iPad.One thing that I found extremely annoying is when I had the notifications turned on it would take me to the Amazon App Store when I told it to clear the notifications.  I'd think that would only happen if I tapped on a specific notification that was an advertisement.I also purchased the HDMI cable for it and was disappointed in the output of it.  It wasn't horrible, but not something I would use without a specific need to.The micro-USB charging port is HORRIBLE!  If you don't get the cable plugged in just right it will not charge at all--and it makes the device extremely hot to boot.  Always check to make sure you have a charging indicator when you plug in the cable.The extremely expensive case also disappointed me.  It does not fit tight enough and I've accidentally pulled it off several times when I've picked it up by the corner.  It also exacerbates the issue with the placement of the power button.I don't use my tablets to watch movies but when I tried that it seemed to work without problems.  I also don't use them to listen to music and I'm pretty sure I didn't even try that so while the sound is pretty good on the things I've used it for I can't really say how it might be for things that are more sound demanding.  Another thing I don't use it for is reading books--I have an e-Ink Kindle for that.  And I've never used the camera on it.One thing that I find annoying about Android in general is the lack of quality apps available.  Sure, the big name apps from the big companies all work well and I don't have complaints about them, but for some things it is really hard finding a decent app.  Luckily the Kindle Fire versions of apps are usually well done so given the choice I select those.Still, the negatives outweigh the positives and I would still be willing to pay twice as much for an iPad.  Were this a $100 device I'd give it a qualified recommendation, but Amazon markets it as an iPad killer, and that it ain't.
Reviews.Title: Sorely disappointed

Reviews.Author: AmazonFan
Reviews.Content: This is my fouth Kindle...yes, you read that right.  I had gotten the original Fire but found it bulky, heavy and the screen gave off too much glare.  I keep it charged, but seldom use and found myself going back to the prior generation for my reading (which is voracious).  This one "fits" me great.  Love the larger screen, but the device is very slender and easy to hold & store.  The display is simply spectacular and the streaming videos are spoiling me!  The speakers are really incredible for such a small gadget.  Easy to set up and I find the keyboard just fine and no inconvenience to check for battery.  To keep the cost lower I am happy to trade off a few things and for me, Amazon put the money where the bang is - speakers, display.  One thing is that I am not able to read my books as comfortably as one of the older Kindles with the non-glare surface.  In fairness, though, I have had cataract surgery so my eyes are rather sensistive doing close up things.  Love the case and the fact I can just close it and I'm done!Well done, Amazon.  It was worth the wait for me.UPDATE - Sadly, after awhile the browser kept shutting down and automatically putting the device in sleep mode when using WIFI.  This started pretty much right after I got it and thought I must have kept hitting the power button to put it in sleep. It got continually worse until I had to return it.
Reviews.Title: changed rating...and sad about that!!

Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Got this today and it is lovely.  Does not feel cheap and set-up was lightning fast.Things I like a lot:It gets better wi-fi reception than any other device in my place.The screen is lovely and the aspect ration is fantastic for watching HD videos.  There is barely any of the screen blocked out.Downton Abbey is free for Amazon Prime!  I have been happily watching episodes for the past 2 hours.App purchases are easy and so far everything I use is available in the app store.Games play wellThe sound is FANTASTIC.  My smartphone and laptop have Beats audio and the fire is actually better sounding over the speakers.Things I am still figuring out:Syncing of some things here and there.  I got the Epicurious app and cannot figure out how to send ingredient lists to my phone so I can pick up stuff while shopping.Some of my video files from my computer are not supported file formats.  Not the end of the world...but now I have to convert them.I still prefer the look of e-ink for books.  Kindle keyboard, you are still needed.The battery icon does not change when the device is charging and since I have cats that can turn off powerstrips it would be good if it let me know that is was charging successfully.
Reviews.Title: First tablet for me

Reviews.Author: Christine in Long Beach
Reviews.Content: I just got my Kindle Fire 8.9 HD yesterday, so I plan to update the review as I get to know it better.It's my first tablet device and I am, so far, feeling pretty lukewarm.  Initially, I was reluctant to get an iPad because they are more expensive, can't use Flash, and I'm aready familiar with the MS and Android operating systems.  Of course, now Adobe that won't support flash for any tablets, that's a moot point.Visually, this Kindle is fantastic.  Good resolution, readable in different light and from different angles.  I give it high marks for that.  The battery life seems pretty good, but I've been spoiled by my Droid Razr Maxx and now have high standards.The one application I was really looking forward to, to be able to read the New Yorker on my Kindle, is completely buggy.  I spoke with a nice man at Amazon App customer service, and he told me that it's a known problem and the developer (Conde Nast) will need to fix it.  Bummer on that, but I'm hoping for a fix shortly.My biggest complaint is the location of the USB connection - bottom center if you're holding this in "landscape" mode.  I bought the leather cover, which works as a stand, so that we can watch movies, but with the Kindle plugged in, you can't use the stand!  That's CRAZY!  Who among us wouldn't want to keep it plugged in (unless you're in a plane) while watching a movie?  Otherwise, you've drained it completely.  The Kindle Fires from last year have the USB access on the short side - wayyyy more practical.The leather cover has its own issues, and I'll review those on the appropriate page.Interim verdict:  3 out of 5.  Good but not as great as I had hoped for.
Reviews.Title: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly

Reviews.Author: David White
Reviews.Content: I bought my Dad the Kindle Fire for his birthday and it froze constantly.  The replacement has been no better and freezes constantly, also.  If you google kindle freeze on the internet, this problem is all over the place and seems to be a common ailment.
Reviews.Title: Kindle Freezes

Reviews.Author: lloyd a. pulliam
Reviews.Content: Bought this to replace the smaller Kindle my wife has. This is her Christmas present and need I say she couldn't wait till Christmas to start using it! She loves it!!! P.S. three weeks after I bought it Amazon came out with a $50 promotional discount on it. I called them yesterday and asked if they would give the discount to me even though I bought it before they offered it. No problem, they credited my Visa! Amazon you people are AWESOME!!!!!
Reviews.Title: Excellent!

Reviews.Author: Carissa Alexander
Reviews.Content: I don't even have the words as to how amazing my Kindle Fire is.  This is my first kindle and I am amazed at all it can do.  Why get an expensive IPAD, when you can get this kindle.  Also, I love how easy it is to load stuff onto from Amazon.  While my kindle was still in the mail being shipped to me, I had a free book downloaded onto it.  As soon as I turned on my new kindle, the free book was there.  Amazing.  I have also watched a few movies on it from Amazon Prime. Great picture and great sound.  ZERO complaints!
Reviews.Title: LOVE

Reviews.Author: Leonora M. "Leonora M."
Reviews.Content: I've had my Kindle Fire HD for about a week now. I wasn't loving it when I first received it and thought about returning it and purchasing an Ipad or other tablet. The more that I'm using it, the more I like it. I'm not a techie and this is my first tablet. I mainly use this for internet browsing, checking emails, watching movies, and playing a few games. I have not had any crashes or errors. I have been able to side load a couple of apps not available through Amazon and they work fine. I am also able to watch Youtube videos with no problem. I am an Amazon Prime member and also have a subscription to Audible so the easy access for their content is great for me. That was really the reason that I chose this tablet over others. So far, I think I made the right decision.
Reviews.Title: I like it!

Reviews.Author: jade
Reviews.Content: I researched various tablets for a long time before I decided to buy the HD 8.9.  Why did I settle on this one over all the rest?  Because during my research I kept coming back to one fundamental question...what will I use the tablet for?  I'm already an Amazon Prime member and ultimately I decided I wasn’t looking for a work horse tablet to run productivity software; I wanted a right sized media device that also lets me surf the web, check e-mail, run apps and watch YouTube videos.  And I didn’t want to pay a fortune for it.  The HD 8.9 fits that bill nicely.  I travel a lot so I sprung for the 32 Gb version which I highly recommend.A lot has been commented on about the location of the power plug port and design of the power and volume buttons but I found once I got used to the buttons it was pretty easy to find them.  Even though the volume buttons don’t show which increases or lowers the sound it’s actually easy to figure out; up is for louder and down is for lower. But I think the power port would have been better placed at the opposite end of the on/off switch because as it is now you can’t use the case as a stand unless you do what I did and turn the kindle upside down in the case.  That way the power can be plugged into the top allowing use of the case as a stand.As for web browsing I am very satisfied in how the browser works for me.  It’s not the smoothest and fastest browser but it works well enough.  Overall I really like the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 because it fits what I want to use it for.  I use my laptop and desktop for productivity…I use my Kindle for entertainment (video, books, games, surfing the Web).
Reviews.Title: Does everything I want it to do!!

Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I have only owned two tablets The fire 1st gen and now this. I use Amazon alot for shopping as well as my media needs. So when looking into a tablet (and I did compare alot of them) I found that I just wanted to stick with Amazon.My take on the fire HD....The ADS. for me not a problem its only on screen saver(at this time no plans to remove them)Recommendations that appear. Not a problem I happen to like them there. I use on Amazon when looking for new items anyway so them being on home screen to me seems a plus.Silk. It has no adobe flash plug-in. Not a problem with as yet was able to watch youtube mobile and visit all my normal web sites.Reading. I have to say I find reading on it as easy as first Fire even better, It has text-to-speech, and some books can be read by a real person if you also have the audible book. Which is actual kinda of cool. Gave it a try with Acheron by Kenyon which I happen to own in both formats (kindle and audible). It adds a new depth to the story. The x-ray for books is nice as well, was able to get info on the characters on the page and thier role in book.Video. Nice picture and sound has happy with it.Apps. Now apps are a problem seems alot of apps that work on Fire 1st gen do not work on HD. Don't know if its Amazon or developer issue (hope fix is just an update away). That being said there are apps I wanted on Fire 1st gen that do work for the HD which is a plus.Over all Im happy to have updated to the new HD model of the fire (which I owned for a year and was very happy with).Difference I like the bigger screen, more memory, and speakers and the bluetooth is nice. Paired with my Jabbra Steet 2 I was able to leave fire in room and go next door. FYI the control buttons on the Jabbra do work to control music on fire was able to skip song and replay remotly. For me this will allow me to use the music player on Fire more easly while walking vs the 1st gen where I had to do all from screen in bright sun light (not fun). In closing I love my Fire it was great buy if you use Amazon alot for media even if you dont at price and with Amazon's nice customer service give it try, I think you will be happy. I am :)
Reviews.Title: My opinion as it is.

Reviews.Author: Ordinary guy
Reviews.Content: I bought  this Kindle for my wife because she really wanted a I-pad type tablet. The affordable price of this high end Kindle made the choice easy. I took advantage of the AT&T; 4G special offer but will only use this connection occasionally since you go through the included monthly usage quickly.  The Wi-Fi works great off my wireless router and gets better reception throughout my home than other Wi-Fi devices I own.The picture quality is fantastic and the sound is good for such tiny speakers. Hi-def movies really bring out the best of this Kindle.  Lots of useful and fun apps available. NetFlix, Facebook and E-Mail work great. Angry birds fly in HD.We're still on a learning curve but the learning is fun and easy.BTW.  I had to use Amazon's excellent customer service/support because of a Wi-Fi issue.  The service rep solved the problem on the phone quickly and to my complete satisfaction.Very impressive piece of equipment. And, like most electronic devices it doesn't come with an instruction book (setup is easy) AND you have to buy the A/C charger seperately or charge it through your computers USB port (it does come with a USB cable).
Reviews.Title: An early Christmas present

Reviews.Author: aggie93
Reviews.Content: The more I play with the Kindle Fire HD, the more I love it! It takes a little getting used to after the iPad, but the price difference totally makes it worth it.  I don't do anything fancy on it - Facebook, Pinterest, email - so it suits my needs just great. And the movie quality is great! So pleased with my early Christmas present.
Reviews.Title: Love it!

Reviews.Author: bluebell
Reviews.Content: Just received mine and love it! Picture quality is great and sound is really good. Worth every penny.  This is my 2nd Kindle. I also have the Asus tf300 and this beats it hands down. You cant go wrong shopping Amazon. UPDATE-Everyone is complaining about ads on this new kindle fire hd but that is garbage. None on mine. If you want to get rid if those annoying "customers also bought this" ads just go to applications, Amazon home recommendations and select hide.
Reviews.Title: New Kindle is awesome

Reviews.Author: Jack
Reviews.Content: We have only had this unit for three days and haven't spent a lot of time with it yet. Also, this is our first tablet, so we are learning the tricks of the trade, so to speak. I am pleased with the build quality; a solid unit and the screen resolution is fantastic. Wi-fi is fast and the device responds to input as expected. Not thrilled with the ads, but I suppose that is life in today's world. It is a little early for me to give a full review because we need more time with it, so I am rating four stars until we gain some expertice and experience with it.
Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G LTE Wireless Tablet

Reviews.Author: Hojo
Reviews.Content: This Kindle Fire HD 8.9" is incredibly light and thin, I can't believe it!  It operates MUCH faster than the original Kindle Fire and the screen is beautiful, my wife saw a picture of me on it and said "it looks so real like I could just touch you" and it was very easy to download all the programs off of the Cloud onto my the new Kindle.  How did I live life pre-Kindle Fire?  A full entertainment center all in the palm of my hand!
Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9"...more perfect than Glock "perfection"

Reviews.Author: Houstonian
Reviews.Content: I have had to replace this Kindle three time between my two kids in the last four months. With one the original kindle lasted just over one year. With the other the kindle HD Fire only last eight months. In both bases it was the kindle stopped charging and responding. Amazon needs to do something about this. It is just too much of a coincidence.To add insult to injury the replacement for the second was defective as there were lines coming across the screen. thus had to order a third kindle. Amazon what are you doing about these defects.
Reviews.Title: The inconvenience is not worth it.

Reviews.Author: Andrew Butts "College Cinephile"
Reviews.Content: WHY THE FIRE WORKS FOR ME: I've developed an avid passion for reading non-fiction due to the first fire. (More on Binocular Vision at the bottom) I read about a book a month, I write essays for a blog twice a month, and as a student, I found the amazing advantage of having a kindle as an even more portable option to my old, heavy laptop. I could get to my google docs, surf the web, listen to my music, watch media and pretty much satiate all my needs for my laptop save actually typing things out. With the addition of blutooth, I can now do that very easily with a bluetooth keyboard. I like to do alot of casual dining, and I usually read while I'm out and about, so it's great that I can work away at my essays as well. The screen size is apt for long documents, and media consumption without being excessive. With the Marware Vibe case it still just fits in my jacket or cargo pocket and follows me everywhere I go. It's got the right power behind it this time to cut down on the sytem lag present in the old fire.TEXT TO SPEECH: One AWESOME feature I didn't know the Fire had was Text to Speech. It's hidden under the settings while in the reader, under more options. I highly suggest it for the non-fiction reader. This way I can listen to my books at work when I can't be reading them, as well as in my car on the go. Saves a ton on audio books. It does a surprisingly good job with pronunciation and sentence structure, though it's still far from perfect. The lady's voice ends up sounding like British NPR, in that, she sometimes says things a little funny and she reads like it's the news, so it's probably not the best for fiction, but on the whole I know alot of real people that are more difficult to understand.MY ONE CON: The lack of google apps. Particularly Google+ and Hangouts. I was hoping to use the webcam for that...ON THE TOPIC OF BINOCULAR VISION: I can't focus on physical books, I apparently have a problem with my binocular near vision I've only recently found out about where my eyes struggle to focus properly on things up close. Having a kindle on a stand, has allowed me to move books further away, reducing the strain, and unlocked this voracious appetite for books I never knew I had. I always liked the idea of books, people always mistook me for a bookish person, but they couldn't keep my attention, often making me quite tired. Depending on the study you read, up to 7% of the population is affected by this. If you have trouble reading, focusing, or staying awake while reading books, you should ask you optometrist about it, and if so, the Kindle might be just the answer you've been looking for. It has been for me.
Reviews.Title: Perfect for the mobile writer, reader, & student (and those with binocular vision issues!) ALSO HAS TEXT TO SPEECH!

Reviews.Author: Bonnie L Kirby
Reviews.Content: I never thought I would be able to give up my hard copy books until I got my Kindle Fire HD.  What a difference.  I am already reading more.  It's comfortable to hold and easy on the eyes.  Set print font as you like.  Love the games apps and have found so many fun things to do.  I am 63 years old and found this easy to use also.  The pictures are crystal clear HD with fabulous sound for movies, tv and music.  I am also an Amazon Prime Member and would recommend that to anyone as there are great free movies and tv shows.  I like getting the daily Kindle deals and have purchased several books this way for a $$$ savings.  Another feature is the dictionary.  Have used it when reading and come across a word not familiar with.  It is so cool to just click on the word and up pops the definition.  Maybe I am easily amused but for my Senior friends out there....if you are thinking about buying a Kindle Fire HD ...... buy it ... you will not be sorry.
Reviews.Title: ABSOLUTELY LOVE IT

Reviews.Author: Tony "Tony"
Reviews.Content: I have a 1st generation iPad, which I still will use often and like it very much. I was considering the latest iPad, but the cost was a little too high for me to purchase it. Then I thoroughly researched the other various tablets available. I was at a crossroads between the Nexus and the Fire HD.  I purchased the Fire HD due to the very good reviews and how good Amazon's customer service has been for me through the years. And since I've been an Amazon Prime member for the last 6 or so years, I decided to get the Kindle Fire HD.  The first Kindle Fire HD that I bought is for my grand daughter as a Christmas gift.  It is the 7" Kindle Fire HD. When it arrived here to my home (I wanted to thoroughly familiarize myself with it before presenting it to her.), I was very much satisfied with it.  I was then fortunate enough to purchase my 8.9" Kindle Fire HD at $50 off when Amazon ran the 1-day discount!  My Kindle promptly arrived and I'm extremely satisfied with it!  Great job Amazon! There some minor things which I would like, such as a front facing camera, more apps available (which will come in time). But other then those two items, I'm a very satisfied owner!
Reviews.Title: Definitely satisfied with my Kindle Fire HD!

Reviews.Author: Mike Bartlett
Reviews.Content: For someone who does not own a smart phone and probably never will, this is just the perfect device.  My wife had received one from our children for her 70th birthday.  The more I played with it the more that I realized that I needed one!  Of course being a guy, the larger 8.9" HD model would be just right.  I was going to go with another manufacturer and get a 10" model, but I was so impressed with how seamless the unit performed with Amazon content.  It didn't make sense to have two different devices.I would recommend a Kindle Fire HD anytime!
Reviews.Title: The perfect entertainment device

Reviews.Author: Aidan
Reviews.Content: I purchased this for my mother who is not the biggest fan of technology, but she took to this so quickly it was a miracle. I personally have a first generation Kindle Fire and the current iPad 3. I have to say this is a huge improvement over the first generation Kindle Fire and I personally think is very similar to the iPad 3. Side by side the retina image on the iPad is clear and performance wise a bit faster, but the Kindle is just as easy to use and if your looking for something to get online and read books its fantastic. If I did not have an iPad I would purchase a new Fire for myself.
Reviews.Title: Fantastic

Reviews.Author: Rachel
Reviews.Content: I purchased my first Kindle a little over a year ago (Kindle keyboard with 3G) and was completely happy with all the reading I was doing.  I ordered the Fire and wasn't sure how I would like it or use it--but let me tell you--I am using this in ways I never imagined and I am so happy with this purchase.  I like being able to see all the covers of the books I purchase in color--something that was missing on the Kindle keyboard with 3G.  Additionally, I would have never believed that I would be using this reader to do anything but reading--but I was feeling under the weather and decided to get comfy and try watching one of the many videos available with my Prime account on my new Kindle Fire.  I am now hooked on Downton Abbey--almost through with Season 2.  This great device is an entertainment mecca--and I didn't even know I wanted to be entertained, lol!  Thinking of canceling my cable television as I feel that I don't need it at this point.  Don't hesitate to jump in with both feet and purchase a Kindle Fire today--you won't be disappointed . . .
Reviews.Title: I absolutely love my new Kindle Fire!  Great product--cannot believe I waited so long to purchase.

Reviews.Author: Pamela M. Fox
Reviews.Content: I have waited over a year to get a Kindle and glad I did to get this model. I am LOVING it - my main purpose was for reading - of course it does a wonderful job with that!! It is hard to put it down!
Reviews.Title: Finally

Reviews.Author: Herky
Reviews.Content: My husband and I both use the device to watch TV shows.  The streaming feature is really nice and works great for traveling.  Prime is essential if you are going to do this because there is so much free content.  The picture is beautiful---works great on the airplane.  If you need to actually download something because there is no Internet somewhere you are going it usually only takes about 10minutes for a 2 hour movie.
Reviews.Title: Great device for the money

Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: We just got a Kindle Fire HD 8.9 for my wife and 6 year old daughter.  By comparison I have a Transformer Prime with the latest Android operating system (Jelly bean).  I can't overstate how impressed I am by The Kindle Fire HD.  The 8.9" screen feels better in my hands than a 10".  On the other hand a 7" just seems like its for a child only.  The screen is stunning and the dual speakers with Dolby surround blow my Prime out of the water (which isn't saying much in terms of sound).  Don't get me wrong, if you're an Android pro/geek than you will prefer a pure Google experience and Jelly Bean is sweet but the Kindle Fire is w/o doubt THE family tablet.  The Kindle Freetime makes setting a profile for your kids so easy and you don't have to worry about them screwing something up which is why I didn't get a Nexus 7.  I can't wait for the upcoming release of Kindle Freetime Unlimited.
